headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Megan, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Vulcan Materials 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Hill, President a
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Megan, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Vulcan Materials 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom Hill, President and CEO of Vulcan Materials Company, you may begin your conference.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us to discuss our fourth quarter 2014 results. I'm Tom Hill, President and Chief Executive Officer of Vulcan. Joining me today is John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. A slide p
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us to discuss our fourth quarter 2014 results. I'm Tom Hill, President and Chief Executive Officer of Vulcan. Joining me today is John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. A slide presentation will accompany this webcast. It will be posted on the company's website at the conclusion of this earnings call.
Before we begin, the actual results and projections, I refer you to Slide 2 of our presentation regarding forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Descriptions of these are detailed in the company's SEC reports, including our most recent report on Form 10-K. 
In addition, during this call, management will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measurements. You can find the reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and other related information in our earnings release and at the end of this presentation.
Before we get into details today, I'd like to speak to you about some things that are immensely important to me and our management team. We executed well in 2014, particularly in the fourth quarter and I'm proud of our people and the job they did and we are focused on the future. When I think about the job our people will need to do in 2015, 3 words come to mind: Momentum, execution and discipline. 
Momentum. We're seeing accelerated momentum in demand throughout our markets. Demand in the fourth quarter exceeded our expectations despite our California business being waterlogged, and recall that we are comparing against a strong fourth quarter in 2013. There is accelerating pricing momentum in many of our markets and we are going to reap the benefits of that momentum. The momentum that we've seen thus far, will carry forward through 2015 and likely well beyond. We are going to take every advantage of it.
Execution. Our team, throughout the company, are executing very well. We were pleased with the results detailed in today's press release and these outcomes directly reflect the great efforts of our people at all levels of the business. In particular, I'm proud of how our local businesses have continued to convert incremental revenues into incremental gross profit. We are servicing our customers well and helping them grow while operating our business safely and efficiently. Despite only modest gains in pricing so far, our people are making the most of this initial phase of recovery. They have set the stage for even stronger performance ahead. My personal focus in 2015 and the focus of our management teams will be on pricing improvements, margin expansion, smart uses of capital and safety.
Discipline. We are very well aware that now is the time for continued to discipline, not congratulations or complacency. Our people will continue to show great discipline in the delivery of quality products and services to our customers safely and efficiently, and we will emphasize continued discipline in how we deploy capital and in how we pursue price and margin improvement. We will be highly focused in 2015 on accelerating gains and pricing for our core aggregates business, so we earn a fair and full return from significant investments that we have made in our business. We have made progress. We are not where we need to be. It is also paramount that we continue our disciplined performance and operational excellence and cost control. We will remain extremely disciplined in our use of capital, deploying it to further build on our strategic base of world-class assets while improving our balance sheet and our return on shareholders capital. 
The momentum, execution and discipline that were hallmarks of 2014 will be our watch words as we build an ever stronger business in 2015.
Now let's move onto the rest of the call. You will see that many of these slides line up with those used in our third quarter call. In large part because our focus on driving improved margins and fully capitalizing on the recovery of demand has not changed.
The results on Slide 4, demonstrate the quality of our fourth quarter execution and how we continue the strong conversion of incremental revenues to growth and earnings. Adjusted EBITDA was $172 million, a 32% increase. We achieved these results despite a temporary rise in SAG costs as a result of business development and performance-based incentives. Our underlying profitability continue to improve significantly, further measured by margin percentage per unit profit. Earnings per share for the quarter of $0.29, including $0.02 per business development expenses and restructuring costs.
On Slide 5, you can see that our fourth quarter results continue to trend in recent quarters. Looking at full year results, you've seen a 38% gain in gross profit on 8% gain in revenues. That significant increase is due to margin discipline particularly in our core aggregates business and the positive impact on the divestiture of our lower margin concrete and cement businesses in Florida. SAG was up due to the items just mentioned. You will see later that we forecast the decline in SAG going forward. Adjusted EBIT nearly doubled for the year and adjusted EBITDA was up handsomely. For the year, adjusted earnings per share were $0.91, including the Florida divestiture and debt tender offer, earnings per share were $1.56. Now turning to our core aggregates segment.
Slide 6 tells the story of volume growth across Vulcan's footprint in 2014. This growing momentum is driven by strength in private construction activity across all end-use markets and an increasing number of large projects, along with increasing highway demand. These trends gained further momentum in the fourth quarter with shipments growing 15% in total and 12% on a same-store basis, even with the impact of bad weather in California and Georgia. 
For the full year, Florida, Georgia, Illinois, Texas and Virginia saw shipments increased by more than 10% on a same-store basis. Aggregates shipments in California and North Carolina also realized solid growth. Shipments in Alabama and South Carolina were down slightly with slower recovery in construction activity in these states.
Now let's talk about how we are converting this momentum and these early gains and demand into expanding margins and profits. Last quarter, we discussed the 3 major profit drivers that we can focus on. 
As you can see on the right-hand side of Slide 7, our industry-leading gross profit per ton increased $0.66 in spite of a modest overall price improvement of $0.21 per ton. Cash gross profit per ton increased to $5.18, 11% gain over a year ago. Our local management teams are doing an outstanding job of turning demand growth into even higher levels of profitability by managing the mix of price, operating efficiencies, sales and products.
This is not a new story for us. As you can see on Slide 8, we have compounded unit profitability faster than pricing for the last 6 quarters. During the last 12 months, our freight adjusted average unit price has increased 2% or $0.25 per ton. Over that same period, our gross profit per ton has increased 18% or $0.52 per ton. Excluding our 2014 acquisitions, trailing 12-month gross profit per ton was up $0.56 or 20%. This is a higher figure than when these operations were producing twice the volume. We are completely focused on ensuring that our unit margins continue to grow.
In speaking to you last quarter about our incremental margin leverage, we discussed our best-in-class incremental flow through that we enjoy with volume growth. Slide 9 depicts incremental margin performance in our aggregate segment. As you can see, incremental gross profit margin for the fourth quarter was 79% excluding the impact of acquisitions completed during the year. 
Aggregates gross profit grew $45 million on incremental freight adjusted revenues of $57 million. Including the impact of acquisitions, the incremental margin was 65%, reduced due to acquisition accounting. Since quarterly figures can be distorted by seasonality or one-time costs, we're also presenting the same metric calculated on a trailing 12-month basis. We encourage you to focus on these numbers. 
For the trailing 12 months ending this quarter incremental gross profit margin was 66% adjusted for the same acquisitions. Aggregates gross profit increased approximately $132 million on incremental freight adjusted revenues of $201 million. Given our strategic focus on the aggregates business, our gross profit flow-through is an advantage to Vulcan as volumes continue to recover.
Slide 10 highlights our asphalt and concrete results for the fourth quarter and full year. Earnings results in each of these segments improved versus the prior year on higher sales. Asphalt gross profit for the full year improved $5 million due to higher margins and earnings from existing operations and for the acquisitions in Arizona and New Mexico. On a same-store basis, asphalt volumes increased 4% in the prior year and unit profitability increased 6% driving a same-store gross profit improvement of $3 million. 
Full year concrete gross profits were $2 million versus a loss of $25 million in the prior year. Excluding the company's divested concrete business, unit profitability improved and gross profit increased $6 million.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to John for some comments on capital allocation and our outlook. John?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. In our last earnings release and call, we placed emphasis on capital allocation particularly with a view toward putting the recent acquisitions we made in the context of our overall approach and plans. The topic of capital allocation remains,
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. In our last earnings release and call, we placed emphasis on capital allocation particularly with a view toward putting the recent acquisitions we made in the context of our overall approach and plans. The topic of capital allocation remains, obviously a critical area of focus for the management team. With that in mind, I'd like to now use Slide 11 to recap our actions during 2014, update you on the transactions we closed last week and highlight the goals and options we have in front of us.
As you know in early 2014, we successfully divested of our Florida area cement and ready-mix concrete operations to Argos. Given our aggregates focus strategy, Argos was a better owner of those assets than we were. As a reminder, our divested cement and concrete operations were among the most volatile and capital-intensive businesses in our portfolio. We remain very pleased with our transaction and it has positioned us very well for Florida's continued recovery and construction activity.
Also during 2014, we further strengthened both our balance sheet and our core profitability. Our ratio of total debt to trailing 12-month EBITDA has improved to approximately 3.3 versus 5.4 a year ago, and it should decline further with continued EBITDA growth in 2015. 
As Thomas noted, our core profitability as measured by the cash gross profit we generate for each ton of aggregates shipped, improved another 9% compounding prior year gains and we expect it to improve further moving forward. As I'll touch on in a minute, we expect same-store shipments to grow approximately 8% in 2015 as a recovery and construction activity progresses. We are very comfortable, very comfortable with our credit position and how it is improving toward our stated investment grade targets. 
We spent $225 million on CapEx excluding M&A during 2014. This capital deployment not only maintains our physical plant, but also improves our efficiencies and ability to meet our customers needs. We've now return to more normal levels of what we call maintenance and enhancement CapEx, and we expect this use of capital to grow more in line with shipments going forward. 
In 2014, we deployed $332 million of capital for targeted acquisitions that strengthen our asset base now and for years to come. We've made good progress with the integration of the 7 acquisitions we made during the year and we expect these operations in total to contribute approximately $50 million to our EBITDA in 2015. And as we indicated we would, we began the process of growing our dividend as we grow earnings. 
Each of these actions contributed to the current and long-term value of our company. Equally importantly, they collectively improved our flexibility and optionality moving forward. As we look to 2015 and beyond, we believe we are well positioned to sustain our capital reinvestment, our current asset base, recover and maintain investment grade credit position, we accelerate the return of capital to our shareholders and to prudently pursue attractive bolt-on acquisitions. 
To be clear, we will also consider additional asset divestitures and swaps. We believe it's important for us and for others in our industry to challenge ourselves regarding whether we are the best owner of our individual assets and operations. This logic supported our 2014 transaction with Argos and it underpins a much smaller transaction we closed in late January. 
As noted in our earnings release, we recently concluded an asset swap with Synnex, into which we've exchanged our Southern California ready-mix concrete operations for 13 asphalt plants primarily in Arizona. Under the agreement, we will continue to supply aggregates to exchange concrete operation. Given as operations and strategic focus in these markets, each party should be able to earn a higher return on the exchange assets than the prior owner. This exchange will be immediately accretive to Vulcan and its expected impact is incorporated into our 2015 projections.
Now let me turn to our outlook for 2015 before handing the call back to Tom. I'll begin on Slide 12 with an overview of our outlook for demand for aggregates in the markets we serve. The headline here is that we see another year of high single-digit demand growth as recovery toward normal levels of construction activity continues. The pattern of recoveries increasingly broad-based as we see growth in each of our primary end-use segments and in the clear majority of our geographies. And from what we can see, demand in Vulcan-served markets should continue to grow faster than the U.S. as a whole. 
We certainly cannot predict the future, but we currently anticipate a gradual recovery lasting several more years before we return to aggregates consumption levels consistent with long-term trends. As you can see on the slide, we see aggregates demand from private end uses up 14% to 18% during 2015. The growth in our fourth quarter sales to these end-users reflects the strong underlying momentum. Private growth continues to be driven by the recovery in employment and the continued recovery in single and multi family housing. 
We see demand from public end uses in our markets, up 3% to 5% during 2015. Construction momentum remains positive and stable in Vulcan markets, south and west continue to see more growth in other areas of the U.S. and that state and local tax revenues approach all-time highs and should provide the support for new public infrastructure funding. 
Our 2015 outlook for these end-use markets, although tailored to our specific mix of geographies, is not vary significantly from the consensus of external industry at. And finally of note, that we have not significantly altered our 2015 demand forecast  or account for recent declines in oil prices, status of federal highway build negotiations or shifting predictions regarding interest rates and credit availability. Certainly these factors introduce a degree of uncertainty, but at this point, we see a continuation of the momentum witnessed over the past 6 quarters. As always, we'll monitor actual local demand patterns throughout the year and respond accordingly.
I'll turn now to Slide 13 for a summary of our full year outlook. I'll be brief as we've touched on many of these items in our press release as well as earlier in this call. We are, for 2015, giving a range for adjusted EBITDA excluding the gains associated with the sale of property of between $775 million and $825 million. I'll touch now on the certain of the assumptions underpinning that EBITDA projection. 
We currently project 2015 aggregate shipments of approximately 180 [ph] million tons consistent with the demand outlook I just highlighted, as well as with the continued strong sales and customer service execution at the local level. On a same-store basis, excluding the impact of acquisitions made in 2014, we project shipments to be up 8% over the prior year. We currently expect average aggregate selling prices on a freight adjusted basis to be at 6% over the prior year. As a reminder, our pricing decisions are made locally and outcomes will vary significantly by geography and at different points in the year. 
But as Tom noted earlier in this call as well as in our prior call, we've seen the pricing environment continue to improve with the recovery in demand, and we remain intensively focused on earning a full and fair return on the investments we've made to serve our customers. We expect total gross profit for the aggregates segment to be approximately $735 million. Margins per ton should expand further as we work not only to achieve higher pricing, but also to leverage fixed cost and maintain strong production efficiencies and cost controls. 
Over the course of the full year, the flow through of incremental freight adjusted revenue to segment gross profit should remain consistent with recent trend, although as we've said, results will fluctuate quarter-to-quarter. For our non-aggregate business segments, we expect gross profit of approximately $70 million in total. This projection reflects the impact of the asset swap I mentioned previously, and includes approximately $50 million of gross profit from our asphalt operations, approximately $17 million of gross profit from our concrete operations and approximately $3 million in gross profit from our calcium business. 
Please note that the actual material margins and gross profit margins from these downstream businesses can vary substantially at the local market level and throughout the year. SAG expenses excluding acquisition and divestiture-related costs and other items should be approximately $265 million in 2015. We remain very focused on leveraging SAG to revenues as volumes recover. 
We expect DD&A for 2015 to be approximately $270 million as compared to $279 million in 2014 and we currently plan to spend $250 million for maintenance and enhancement capital in 2015. Excluding our capital spending for acquisitions are significant expansion of our distribution and logistics capabilities. 
Now a couple of final notes before I hand in the call back to Tom. First, I should remind everyone that the projections I just noted are certainly subject to revision throughout the year. While we believe our visibility to demand has been improving as we get further into the early stages of recovery, there certainly remains some uncertainty in the macro environment whether due to oil prices, federal and state transportation funding decisions or other factors. That said, our focus remains on making the most of whatever recovery scenario we are presented with. 
Second, I'll note that our profit projections do not necessarily account the full production cost benefits we may realize if diesel prices were to remain at current levels throughout the year. Our production budgets are built bottom up, plant by plant, and our operators remain focused as of course they should be, on the efficiencies within their control. We'll do our best to note the impact of shifting energy costs on our business as the year unfolds. With that, I'll turn the call back over to Tom for a closing comment.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. We were pleased with our fourth quarter performance, but our eyes are on what's in front of us. Last year, we put down a solid foundation. Now we will build on it. We're going to be highly focused on superior execution of the business, price
componenttext:
Thanks, John. We were pleased with our fourth quarter performance, but our eyes are on what's in front of us. Last year, we put down a solid foundation. Now we will build on it. We're going to be highly focused on superior execution of the business, price improvement, lowering cost, margin growth and capital discipline. The momentum that we found so encouraging in 2014 and it was so apparent in our fourth quarter results will only continue to grow. Along with accelerating demand growth, we're going to see accelerating momentum in our ability to secure price improvements and in our ability to continue executing on our first class operational discipline, controlling and lowering cost. We fully recognize the importance of executing on price and operational discipline to give our shareholders a superior return on capital. And as I said earlier, we will continue to be extremely disciplined in our allocation of capital. 
Regardless of what the markets may do, we will stay focused on the things that we control, executing on price improvement and margin expansion. We'll also remain focused on servicing our customers so they continue to reap value from the relationships with us. Working together, we will win. I'm excited about our company and its future and I look forward to continuing to report to you as we keep growing and succeeding in the years ahead. Now, if the operator will give the required instructions, we'll be happy to respond to your questions.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015

And then question 2, if prices do stay down throughout this year, will that affect the price of aggregates in the market as the year progresses?

componenttext: I'm sorry, would you repeat your first question?

componenttext: Yes, the first question, if could you give us a rough number of how much diesel fuel you used in '14 gallons or something along those lines?

componenttext: Total gallons we used in '14 was just over 44 million gallons.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and if we see the prices down the way they are now for the rest of the year, will that have a negative effect on aggregate pricing just around the shipping comp?
componenttext: Okay, and if we see the prices down the way they are now for the rest of the year, will that have a negative effect on aggregate pricing just around the shipping comp?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it won't have any affect on pricing. We have a lot of pricing momentum. We do not price on cost. It's market-driven and the value of our products and services to our customers, so the price of oil won't have an impact on the price of aggregates.
componenttext: No, it won't have any affect on pricing. We have a lot of pricing momentum. We do not price on cost. It's market-driven and the value of our products and services to our customers, so the price of oil won't have an impact on the price of aggregates.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Keith, it's John. Also keep in mind, we report freight adjusted pricing, so the impact of diesel on shipping costs won't show up in our freight adjusted pricing.
componenttext: And Keith, it's John. Also keep in mind, we report freight adjusted pricing, so the impact of diesel on shipping costs won't show up in our freight adjusted pricing.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess what I'm getting towards as this could be clearly a big benefit for you this year if this stays down. Would all that benefit accrue to the bottom line or will there be some give back, whether it's around driver cost or anything like that?
componenttext: I guess what I'm getting towards as this could be clearly a big benefit for you this year if this stays down. Would all that benefit accrue to the bottom line or will there be some give back, whether it's around driver cost or anything like that?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't see any place we give back cost savings on fuel. I think when it comes to fuel, what we concentrate on are things we can control, which is using our procurement and management systems to buy fuel at the most competitive prices we can, and then we
componenttext: I don't see any place we give back cost savings on fuel. I think when it comes to fuel, what we concentrate on are things we can control, which is using our procurement and management systems to buy fuel at the most competitive prices we can, and then we monitor fuel usage at every location, over 300 locations we manage the tons per gallon of fuel we use, so that we make sure that our equipment, our operating equipment is fuel efficiently as we possibly can.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Final question on Slide 6, you have Texas as one of your really good market share in 2014. We all know the questions around that, can you give us any sort of scale for what Texas represents for the company?
componenttext: Final question on Slide 6, you have Texas as one of your really good market share in 2014. We all know the questions around that, can you give us any sort of scale for what Texas represents for the company?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, we feel very little directly to the oil patch in Texas, so the immediate impacts, we're not going to see any. There is a lot of momentum in Texas, residential, nonresidential. Texas just passed top 1, which is an additional $1.8 billion
componenttext: Yes, first of all, we feel very little directly to the oil patch in Texas, so the immediate impacts, we're not going to see any. There is a lot of momentum in Texas, residential, nonresidential. Texas just passed top 1, which is an additional $1.8 billion to the highway funding, which is also right in our wheelhouse because a lot of that is focused on little markets where we operate. We just think there's a lot of momentum there. At this point, we don't see anything happening for 2 or 3 quarters after that. I'm not sure we want to predict it, but there's a lot of folks out there predicting that.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quickly back to your first question on diesel and its impacts in aggregates pricing. Just a reminder that diesel is a relatively small portion of our total production cost, about 7%-ish [ph] of. So our biggest costs and our product is the stone, the asset
componenttext: Quickly back to your first question on diesel and its impacts in aggregates pricing. Just a reminder that diesel is a relatively small portion of our total production cost, about 7%-ish [ph] of. So our biggest costs and our product is the stone, the asset, the we own and we price to return on that, so minor fluctuations up and down and 10% of our cost isn't going to affect our pricing strategy.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Kathryn Thompson from Thomson research group.

componenttext: To your first question, I don't know that I'm going to give you a specific bogey. I'd underscore that our focus both now and long-term is full return on the full asset base, and particularly because we've made those billions of dollars of investment on behalf of our customers to serve them well. And so I'm pleased with our current results and pleased with the margin expansion and pleased with the outlook for '15. There's further to go on that, much further to go. And your second question was actions to accelerate -- what was that, Kathryn?

componenttext: My final question, I know that you don't have a significant amount of volumes that goes specifically into the oil industry or the energy industry, but have you taken a stab at quantifying your best estimate of what percentage of your volume specifically go to the energy industry?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said earlier, very little goes directly to the oil patch. We'll ship over 2 million tons to large coastal energy projects in 2015. Those jobs are underway or getting underway. They won't be postponed. There is a few jobs that have not -- there'
componenttext: Well, as I said earlier, very little goes directly to the oil patch. We'll ship over 2 million tons to large coastal energy projects in 2015. Those jobs are underway or getting underway. They won't be postponed. There is a few jobs that have not -- there's a few projects on the coast that we're hearing rumors of delay, but they would not hit until '16 or '17 anyway.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Trey Grooms with Stevens.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Trey Grooms with Stevens.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quick question on the mix impact on price, and my call dropped off for a second, so forgive me if you guys did touch on this. Is that largely behind you guys or is there any anticipation that, that could creep into 1Q or any other period for that matter?
componenttext: Quick question on the mix impact on price, and my call dropped off for a second, so forgive me if you guys did touch on this. Is that largely behind you guys or is there any anticipation that, that could creep into 1Q or any other period for that matter?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the mix issue was we sold big projects in -- up and down the Mississippi river and in Illinois. While those were at lower prices, they were very good volumes. I think the fourth quarter headline pricing, relies the pricing momentum that we'r
componenttext: Well, I think the mix issue was we sold big projects in -- up and down the Mississippi river and in Illinois. While those were at lower prices, they were very good volumes. I think the fourth quarter headline pricing, relies the pricing momentum that we're seeing across our footprint. If you kind of step back and look at pricing in the fourth quarter on a market by market basis, and we look at the markets where we're seeing higher growth or where the recovery is a little more mature, I'll read this off to you. We're seeing price increases in the fourth quarter 7.8, 6.5, increase of 5.8%, 5.7%, 4.8, 4.6. Now offsetting that in some of the markets where recovery is not as far along or where we sold some big basin job, we're seeing price increases in the fourth quarter of 2%, flat-flat, minus 1% or minus 1.4%, and that's not all bad because if you look at the margin expansion across that same footprint, we're seeing nice margin expansion in almost all of our markets, so as far as pricing going into 2015, there's a lot of -- we're confident that the conditions and the momentum is there for good price increases. I'm focused on it and I think our team is focused on it and we're secure about our pricing outlook for '15.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful, Tom. And then my second question is a lot of talk, obviously around infrastructure funding, the President's budget proposal called for an increase there again. I think the current bill expires in May, if I'm not mistaken. What are you guys
componenttext: That's helpful, Tom. And then my second question is a lot of talk, obviously around infrastructure funding, the President's budget proposal called for an increase there again. I think the current bill expires in May, if I'm not mistaken. What are you guys looking for? I know you guys are pretty in tune with what's going on in Washington, what's being kicked around. What are you guys looking for if you were to take a best guess on how things shake out in May? And then as we kind of look into '15, any hopes further for some type of a longer-term bill?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're seeing a lot of positive momentum for a new highway bill. Leadership of both parties stated their intention to pass a well-funded bill. The timing, that's not clear. It may be difficult to get a bill by May, but we made an extension, but Congress ha
componenttext: We're seeing a lot of positive momentum for a new highway bill. Leadership of both parties stated their intention to pass a well-funded bill. The timing, that's not clear. It may be difficult to get a bill by May, but we made an extension, but Congress has shown over and over again, that they're going to fund the highway program and so extension may have to happen and it will. The lack of highway bill is not going to hurt us. The highway bill is not in our outlook. It could only help us and we think there's a reasonably good chance of getting a new bill in 2015.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So then, with your assumptions and guidance, I think you said public is going to be up 3% to 5%. What is the -- it sounds like you're going under the assumption there won't be a new highway bill in that, but what's driving the 3% to 5% in a flat kind of f
componenttext: So then, with your assumptions and guidance, I think you said public is going to be up 3% to 5%. What is the -- it sounds like you're going under the assumption there won't be a new highway bill in that, but what's driving the 3% to 5% in a flat kind of funding environment that's in the guidance.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. If you look at our -- we've got a number of very large jobs that we'll be supplying in '15, the Grand Parkway in Houston, 5 75, 5 75 -- 5 75 in Atlanta, so there are a number of very large jobs across our footprint that we started
componenttext: That's a good question. If you look at our -- we've got a number of very large jobs that we'll be supplying in '15, the Grand Parkway in Houston, 5 75, 5 75 -- 5 75 in Atlanta, so there are a number of very large jobs across our footprint that we started in '14 and will really kick in, in '15. There is some other pieces of that. We've got 6 TIFIA jobs that will ship in 2015, it will be north of 2 million tons in '15 for those jobs, but you're starting to see the TIFIA program really mature from people talking about jobs or planning jobs to actually shipping materials on them, and then we've seen a number of state highways increase their funding in Florida, Nova Scott, announced $10 billion highway bill for this coming year. Texas, as I mentioned earlier, passed Prop 1, which is an initial $1.8 billion. We've gotten more funding in Virginia, Georgia as we got a proposal for increase of $1 billion, so the state funding is up on top of all that.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tray, one thing that I'd lust point out on all that is our funding environment in our states, in our markets is not flat. If you look at the TIFIA projects, when you look at the rise at the state and local funding, if you look at the rises in deployment o
componenttext: Tray, one thing that I'd lust point out on all that is our funding environment in our states, in our markets is not flat. If you look at the TIFIA projects, when you look at the rise at the state and local funding, if you look at the rises in deployment of funding the projects, our markets have funding increase consistent with our 3% to 5% outlook for our markets.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: First up, great quarter. That was very impressive both in terms of the revenue performance and profitability. Slide 8 caught my eye, you have a big improvement in rolling gross profit per ton on a 12-month basis, and I was hoping whether you can -- you po
componenttext: First up, great quarter. That was very impressive both in terms of the revenue performance and profitability. Slide 8 caught my eye, you have a big improvement in rolling gross profit per ton on a 12-month basis, and I was hoping whether you can -- you posted $3.35 a ton, where can that go to in 2015 given the demand profile and the initiatives?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we expect to see, I'd say 2 things. We'd expect to see our incremental margin or incremental revenue, freight adjusted revenue in the aggregate segment to remain consistent with past trends for next year, and along with, I don't think you'd see si
componenttext: I think we expect to see, I'd say 2 things. We'd expect to see our incremental margin or incremental revenue, freight adjusted revenue in the aggregate segment to remain consistent with past trends for next year, and along with, I don't think you'd see similar increases in unit profitability. I come back to the point about earning a return on capital over time. We have a quite a long ways to go in terms of margin performance to tie back to the kind of returns on capital we'd like to see. So not only do we have room in '15, I think we have room for very long time. You can go on a gross profit basis next year, I think if you work through the math, I think north of $4 on a trailing 12-month basis is sort of within our sites, and that's in the gross profit basis and a cash basis, you could see north of 5 25. Keep in mind that our current levels of profitability, as Tom mentioned on a unit basis are higher than a benefit pass while we're still operating it, a little more than half the volumes we produced in the past. But with the kind of pricing we see in front of us, with the leverage of fixed cost we see in front of us, we're very focused on improving those numbers.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, it's actually what I was looking for. I just wanted to ask Tom, it seems like you have some good visibility on some heavy tonnage jobs coming up, and I was hoping you already addressed kind of what you're seeing on the public side. What are your exp
componenttext: Okay, it's actually what I was looking for. I just wanted to ask Tom, it seems like you have some good visibility on some heavy tonnage jobs coming up, and I was hoping you already addressed kind of what you're seeing on the public side. What are your expectations for private nonresidential and private residential? And if I could just dovetail that, how confident are you in kind of the 8% same-store volume growth and the 11%? Is it more confident now than you were 12 months ago?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we're very confident in our outlook. When we do these bottom-up, our guys and gals come in each core, in each market to build volume up. As far as -- we had a very good 2014 in non-res. Some of that driven by traditional non-res, construction of o
componenttext: I think we're very confident in our outlook. When we do these bottom-up, our guys and gals come in each core, in each market to build volume up. As far as -- we had a very good 2014 in non-res. Some of that driven by traditional non-res, construction of office buildings, big-box, strip malls. On top of that, we saw the bulk from the large projects along the Gulf coast. We'll continue to see that. There's a lot of confidence out there in the marketplace, with our sales people and our customers for non-res. As I said earlier, we -- our shipments to the large energy projects along the coast will be higher in '15 as those projects mature than they were in 14.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: As another reminder, Tom always points this out, but despite the good growth numbers over the last 6 quarters, we're nowhere near normal levels of demand or construction activity in the vast majority of our markets. Nowhere near. So we both have a little
componenttext: As another reminder, Tom always points this out, but despite the good growth numbers over the last 6 quarters, we're nowhere near normal levels of demand or construction activity in the vast majority of our markets. Nowhere near. So we both have a little bit better visibility. We've got good momentum as you've seen in the last 6 quarters in the fourth quarter. The part of our confidence as a reminder to folks, is we're still getting volume growth just out of recovery from a deep trough in demand. It's not predicated upon dramatic overall economic growth in the U.S. Its recovery of construction activity to things that begin to look like sustainable levels.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how we should think about costs in the aggregate division. I appreciate that diesel is a relatively small portion of the cost, but are we also are aware that the sensitivity of a 10% moving diesel is pre
componenttext: Just wondering if you could talk a little bit about how we should think about costs in the aggregate division. I appreciate that diesel is a relatively small portion of the cost, but are we also are aware that the sensitivity of a 10% moving diesel is pretty significant, so as we think of potentially a lower diesel, think about incremental margin at least within your guidance as consistent with prior trends, are there any cost offsets to the potential diesel benefit whether it's in blasting or explosives or contract and services or any other items that we should be aware of?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, we do these plans there from a bottom-up perspective with over 300 locations plus a country, so everybody is using a different fuel cost. Embedded in that is also Off-Road and On-Road diesel and that mix changes. We're trying to get a solid
componenttext: First of all, we do these plans there from a bottom-up perspective with over 300 locations plus a country, so everybody is using a different fuel cost. Embedded in that is also Off-Road and On-Road diesel and that mix changes. We're trying to get a solid comparison for a diesel price is really tough. Now there maybe some savings embedded in it, but as I said earlier, our focus will be on the things that we can control, which is how we buy it and buy it as economically as we can and then how we use it, with measuring tons per gallon. So there may be some embedded there, but that's really hard to define and take apart across our footprint. As far as other cost of concern, there's always different commodities we use. We do have price increases in a number of those, I think we also have the operating leverage, but I think we'll turn in, continue to turn in improved pricing numbers as the year progresses and I think our folks are really doing a good job focusing on key drivers of cost. Now you also got to remember, we're still operating at 60-something -- a little north of 60% of our peak volumes, so we've got a lot of room to be able to optimize our operations and our cost as volumes continue to grow.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, it's John. There's only really one area in cost where I think we see a major trend that we're resting with the guys resting with, it jumps out. That's not direct offset to diesel per se, but repair cost remain an ongoing challenge for us, not a maj
componenttext: Garik, it's John. There's only really one area in cost where I think we see a major trend that we're resting with the guys resting with, it jumps out. That's not direct offset to diesel per se, but repair cost remain an ongoing challenge for us, not a major thing. We're working on that ties to our CapEx focus over time, but we don't see major increases, I'm calling it inflationary increases at the moment and keep in mind, we own our major input.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: My second question is on asphalt. Your guidance implies I think it's about a 30% increase in profitability. Your volume guidance when we look at infrastructure demand for the year, low to mid-single digits. That's strong leverage. I'm just wondering maybe
componenttext: My second question is on asphalt. Your guidance implies I think it's about a 30% increase in profitability. Your volume guidance when we look at infrastructure demand for the year, low to mid-single digits. That's strong leverage. I'm just wondering maybe if you can provide a little more color on the drivers behind the asphalt profitability, is it more margin expansion of liquid asphalt costs or is it in the end market that you're servicing on the asphalt side, you're seeing accelerated volume growth or I guess, is it the acquisition or is it the asset swaps that you engage in that's going to be driving most of the profit improvement?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that -- we do have some improvement in our existing operations. It's a little volume there and some margin expansion, but the big jump there is with our acquisitions and the swap, and the asphalt operations that we acquired. I think if you look at
componenttext: I think that -- we do have some improvement in our existing operations. It's a little volume there and some margin expansion, but the big jump there is with our acquisitions and the swap, and the asphalt operations that we acquired. I think if you look at it, the asphalt business, we're going to show gross profit improvement of about $15 million, about $12.5 million of that is acquisitions, about $2.5 million of that is improved volume and unit margins on existing businesses.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of Ted Grace with Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of Ted Grace with Susquehanna.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to kind of focus on capital allocation and just kind of get a sense for how you encourage us to think about the dry powder you've got. To your point, John, exited last year at about 5.5x leverage. This year, you'll be exiting at about 3 on ou
componenttext: I was hoping to kind of focus on capital allocation and just kind of get a sense for how you encourage us to think about the dry powder you've got. To your point, John, exited last year at about 5.5x leverage. This year, you'll be exiting at about 3 on our numbers. At the end of '15, you're kind of sub 2. And so I just want to kind of revisit, how should we think about your targeted capital structure across the cycle? It's kind of the first question.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with where we are and then a couple of comments on cycle. We'll probably touch on this topic more later. First, we're very comfortable with our current leverage ratio -- current amount of leverage. I think what we highlight is we've taken a n
componenttext: Let me start with where we are and then a couple of comments on cycle. We'll probably touch on this topic more later. First, we're very comfortable with our current leverage ratio -- current amount of leverage. I think what we highlight is we've taken a number of actions over the years to get ourselves in a position where we can, a little bit do all of the above, so we can reinvest our businesses as we need to. And our plant and equipment, and our asset base, we can achieve and maintain an investment grade credit rating, which matters to us, so we have access to capital all points of the cycle, to your question on the cycle. So that we can accelerate the return of capital to shareholders whether that's through dividend or other mechanisms over time, so I expect you to see us have more of our cash flow each year give back to shareholders as part of the mix. And so we can still pursue prudent acquisitions and have a strong return like you've seen us do in the last year. I think we've got ourselves in a spot to your point on dry powder. So long as we are prudent and cognizant of the cycle, we can do all of these things. In terms of how we think about it through the cycle, I'm going to say now, we're still close to the trough of the cycle than anything that's normal. We think we've got several years of growth and margin expansion in front of us, and as we -- if we deliver a year like you said Ted,for your model, your expectations, we have a lot of options. And I think the good news is we're going to have a lot of options and we've worked hard to be in that position, but I think we'll have more options than if you will, we'll have trade-off. I think we'll be able to do again the right mix of all of the above.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then maybe as a follow on to that, can you just talk about what the M&A pipeline looks like right now?
componenttext: And then maybe as a follow on to that, can you just talk about what the M&A pipeline looks like right now?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's still healthy. There's still a lot out there, Ted, but I think the important piece of that is discipline. We have to be disciplined about what we're going to buy. We're disciplined about what we pay for it and then as important as anything, disciplin
componenttext: It's still healthy. There's still a lot out there, Ted, but I think the important piece of that is discipline. We have to be disciplined about what we're going to buy. We're disciplined about what we pay for it and then as important as anything, disciplined about how we integrate it and as quickly as we can, bring it up to Vulcan standards of profitability and unit margins. So while there's a lot out there, we'll just have to sure we're disciplined. We're pleased with our '14 acquisitions and I think so far, we're very pleased with integration and looking forward to their adding to our profitability in 2015.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Armstrong with Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most of my questions have been asked, but looking into 2015, are there any regions, which you're capacity-constrained and utilization is higher than that average 50% to 60% you saw in 2014?
componenttext: Most of my questions have been asked, but looking into 2015, are there any regions, which you're capacity-constrained and utilization is higher than that average 50% to 60% you saw in 2014?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wish we had that problem. No, as I said earlier, we're still operating 60% when we're at the peak. We've got a long ways to go before anywhere we consider capacity constraints.
componenttext: I wish we had that problem. No, as I said earlier, we're still operating 60% when we're at the peak. We've got a long ways to go before anywhere we consider capacity constraints.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That helps. And then just a clarification, you paid down a lot of debt in 2014. What's your interest rate likely to be as you go -- or interest expense likely to be as you go into 2015?
componenttext: That helps. And then just a clarification, you paid down a lot of debt in 2014. What's your interest rate likely to be as you go -- or interest expense likely to be as you go into 2015?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'd say roughly $160 million, but I think you should expect us to continue as a company to take a hard look at our debt portfolio and its coupon cost and its duration and those kind of things back to those questions about some of the options we have in fr
componenttext: I'd say roughly $160 million, but I think you should expect us to continue as a company to take a hard look at our debt portfolio and its coupon cost and its duration and those kind of things back to those questions about some of the options we have in front of us. I think if you're modeling, I think about $160 million roughly net interest expense, I think, and which is roughly consistent over last year. Part of our debt paydown last year was a use of proceeds from the divestiture of Argos. We're now in a position where as I said, we're very comfortable with our current level of debt and our credit standing.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Timna Tanners with Merrill Lynch.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to clarify one of the things that you said earlier, and I've asked this in the past, and I just kind of want to just get your take on it. When you talk about your visibility improving as the demand growth, what does that mean exactly and how f
componenttext: I just want to clarify one of the things that you said earlier, and I've asked this in the past, and I just kind of want to just get your take on it. When you talk about your visibility improving as the demand growth, what does that mean exactly and how far out is your visibility?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're looking at 2000 [ph] -- we're really talking about 2015 and the reason the visibility gets better is you're starting to see, your backlogs are solid, you have confidence of jobs in your -- of coming up and your contractors and your sal
componenttext: Well, I think we're looking at 2000 [ph] -- we're really talking about 2015 and the reason the visibility gets better is you're starting to see, your backlogs are solid, you have confidence of jobs in your -- of coming up and your contractors and your sales force, as you feel the momentum for like example in the residential, you're not building out subdivisions anymore. You're starting use of divisions, which are much more aggregate-intensive, so you just get a feel for the confidence and you start to see the jobs that you have secured much larger and more numerous.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then along those lines, if we were to get some sort of action from the government regarding a way to finance and finally pass a multi-year highway spending program, is it fair to say that the real benefit would start to flow through more into 20
componenttext: Okay, and then along those lines, if we were to get some sort of action from the government regarding a way to finance and finally pass a multi-year highway spending program, is it fair to say that the real benefit would start to flow through more into 2016, 2017? How do you think about what that would look like?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think based on the timing, that's spot on, that will the bill, it has to flow through, you have to get jobs ready, so I think you'd be looking at '16 and '17.
componenttext: I think based on the timing, that's spot on, that will the bill, it has to flow through, you have to get jobs ready, so I think you'd be looking at '16 and '17.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Stanley Elliott with Stifle.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Stanley Elliott with Stifle.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Quick question, just from a timing perspective with some of the weather issues last year, should we expect the cadence of the volumes through the year to be materially different or kind of more of a normal seasonality?
componenttext: Quick question, just from a timing perspective with some of the weather issues last year, should we expect the cadence of the volumes through the year to be materially different or kind of more of a normal seasonality?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I could predict the weather, I'd answer that question. The first quarter and the fourth quarter are always dicey. You just never know what's going to happen. What we're talking about in the presentation was, last year our fourth quarter, had great weat
componenttext: If I could predict the weather, I'd answer that question. The first quarter and the fourth quarter are always dicey. You just never know what's going to happen. What we're talking about in the presentation was, last year our fourth quarter, had great weather, was really strong, so we were very pleased with the performance in this year's fourth quarter versus 2013. I don't know how to answer that except for if you look at it, we just have to base it on normal weather patterns, which would mean first and fourth quarters are always a little dicey.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's John, real quick. This is not like an answer to your question directly, but it may be related point, which I think there is historically that have been a tendency is you all model quarterly results, if you will, over model a first quarter and just --
componenttext: It's John, real quick. This is not like an answer to your question directly, but it may be related point, which I think there is historically that have been a tendency is you all model quarterly results, if you will, over model a first quarter and just -- I'd just remind you that first quarter results get a typically low volumes and erratic weather, it can be a little more unpredictable whether that's a question on price or cost, so I would say that people often fail to understand some of the volatility that's inherent in the first quarter.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: As far as the SAG cost, we see some nice leverage in the coming year, but outside of acquisitions or incentive comp, is there any reason to think that, that number cannot continue to be leveraged on a go forward basis in [indiscernible] '16 and beyond?
componenttext: As far as the SAG cost, we see some nice leverage in the coming year, but outside of acquisitions or incentive comp, is there any reason to think that, that number cannot continue to be leveraged on a go forward basis in [indiscernible] '16 and beyond?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we fully intend to leverage that number in '16 and beyond, and Tom would say exactly the same thing. And when we took a bunch of actions to reduce SAG costs, we worked hard to do it in a way where it can be leveraged going forward, including systems i
componenttext: No, we fully intend to leverage that number in '16 and beyond, and Tom would say exactly the same thing. And when we took a bunch of actions to reduce SAG costs, we worked hard to do it in a way where it can be leveraged going forward, including systems investments and other things we've done. So that is our intent and focus.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: As John likes to say, we've been through that pain, we're not going back there.
componenttext: As John likes to say, we've been through that pain, we're not going back there.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It doesn't mean the number 1, go up, son, but obviously, if our volumes grow, and I think it will, but as a percent of sales, it should decline significantly over time.
componenttext: It doesn't mean the number 1, go up, son, but obviously, if our volumes grow, and I think it will, but as a percent of sales, it should decline significantly over time.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Todd Vencil with Stern Agee.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Todd Vencil with Stern Agee.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: If I go back to your original comments, Tom, about momentum, obviously you are seeing momentum and volumes continue, 2014 and 2015, you see a momentum in price, sort of picking up 2014 and 2015. You talked about a gradual recovery lasting several more yea
componenttext: If I go back to your original comments, Tom, about momentum, obviously you are seeing momentum and volumes continue, 2014 and 2015, you see a momentum in price, sort of picking up 2014 and 2015. You talked about a gradual recovery lasting several more years, can you give us some sense of whether you think as we look beyond '15, given that you don't have a crystal ball, but could you give us some sense of whether you think momentum can continue to sort of grow and rates of growth can stay at the levels they've been or even expand on price and volume?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: As far as confidence beyond '15 and our outlook there, what gives us confidence is we're so far below the structural demand of aggregates, even with our outlook in '15. And for our country, to stay healthy and strong like it is, that structural demand has
componenttext: As far as confidence beyond '15 and our outlook there, what gives us confidence is we're so far below the structural demand of aggregates, even with our outlook in '15. And for our country, to stay healthy and strong like it is, that structural demand has to continue to grow or get back to more normalized levels, so a lot of the conference there. It's also the momentum you see out there in all segments of the market and yes, as far as continue to expand margins, we plan on as I said earlier continuing disciplined execution of price and our operating disciplines.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015

componenttext: I think, Todd -- the official answer. One, lI can't give an answer on Investor Day early, our guidance is our guidance. So your question within that, I think I'll just refer you back to some of our comments. We haven't tried to bake all the potential benefits of lower diesel prices into our estimates because we don't know what diesel prices are going to be, so that could -- for this year, that could swing a bit, obviously in our production cost as it did in the fourth quarter. So that's an example, but I think you could go through a lot of things and have an example, but that's one just kind of outside of our control, if you will, that we would think about. And again, for that reason, we didn't try to bake in some assumption that we can't control into our models.

How much of that is volumes coming back and you guys are being imprudent on adding back fixed cost, and how much of that is throughput activity improvements you're making to the business?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: There is a lot of that in throughput productivity improvements. As I said earlier, we're operating at 60% of our peak volumes, so you've got plants in some markets where we're having 2 crews cruise run 4 plants and there's just a lot of inefficiencies wit
componenttext: There is a lot of that in throughput productivity improvements. As I said earlier, we're operating at 60% of our peak volumes, so you've got plants in some markets where we're having 2 crews cruise run 4 plants and there's just a lot of inefficiencies with that, along with a lot of fixed cost in these plants. We also need to go back and look at when you can look at margin improvements, that mix, the slide that has the circles on it, it's a mix of price, of cost and then the bloom of the products we're selling, that give you the total -- the total maximized profitability of an operation, we make as much money as you can. And that's why we call it a local market because just the plant manager and the salesman, they have to be there, looking at the stockpiles, looking at what the market is going to have, what's going to go with price to put all that together to maximize profitability.

And then a second and final question, assets held for sale is, it was about [ph]  $4 million to $5 million in the balance sheet, in your forecast for 2015, is there any assumption of higher ongoing land sales in 2015 and in 2014?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Mike, I'll take a first shot at those. First on SAG, I'll just give you a rundown in some of the kind of things we saw in the fourth quarter. A lot of this is business development-related and more than a couple of million dollars. We had some incentive co
componenttext: Mike, I'll take a first shot at those. First on SAG, I'll just give you a rundown in some of the kind of things we saw in the fourth quarter. A lot of this is business development-related and more than a couple of million dollars. We had some incentive comp that was really tied to our Florida divestiture and a gain in that sales as part of our system, so that's a one-time event. We have a significant land donation, another $1.5 million roughly, which ends up as an SAG cost and then down as a gain on sale of land, so that negatively affects EBITDA. We had other costs associated with the acquisitions we made, so a lot of the things that drove SAG were not repeating themselves. Yes, the core is in the comp, we'll keep an eye on as part of our overall business mix, but much of the factors driving the 8 million variance in Q4 and really the variance for the full year, had to do with one-off and nonrecurring items. On your question about assets held for sale, I believe the answer, if you look at the same part of the balance sheet I am, is that those were held -- that was the Synnex swap, and that we knew we were working in that transaction, expected to conclude it, we concluded it in January, so at the time of the balance sheet, we were holding those assets for sale. Rough fair value associated with the asset swap for both sides is about $20 million, just to give you a sense of the size of the transaction, no cash involved.
