componenttext: But that said, don't take that as a signal that we expect some imminent decline in performance.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, on asphalt, very strong -- the incrementals and the margins there tracking well above our expectations. Is there anything going on in the quarter there? Do you expect these trends continue in asphalt? Now I'll turn it over.
componenttext: And then, on asphalt, very strong -- the incrementals and the margins there tracking well above our expectations. Is there anything going on in the quarter there? Do you expect these trends continue in asphalt? Now I'll turn it over.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the asphalt segment was up $12 million. $9 million of that was without the same-store basis. $3 million was the acquisitions. So we're pleased -- you got to remember that asphalt, a lot of asphalt in Texas the Mexico and Arizona. So they did have the
componenttext: Yes, the asphalt segment was up $12 million. $9 million of that was without the same-store basis. $3 million was the acquisitions. So we're pleased -- you got to remember that asphalt, a lot of asphalt in Texas the Mexico and Arizona. So they did have the headwinds of weather, so we're very pleased with our operating group being able to deliver value to our customers, manage material margins and operating costs and give customers service with all that rain. That's tough to do. On top of that, the $3 million improvement from the recent acquisitions, we believe that that's a sign those have been integrated well and quickly. And in that, we got a lot of talent. Glad we add to the team. So both the same-store and acquisitions were pleased with performance. I don't see anything in this that would slow that down at this point.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Trey and for others, I think I'll just remind folks new with our business that we tend to earn pretty good returns on capital and asphalt segment through the cycle and over time. So we're pleased with those investments.
componenttext: And Trey and for others, I think I'll just remind folks new with our business that we tend to earn pretty good returns on capital and asphalt segment through the cycle and over time. So we're pleased with those investments.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson from Thompson Research Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson from Thompson Research Group.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, a clarification from acquisition contribution in the quarter, both on the top line and EBIT or operating margin -- operating earnings contribution? And you may have said this, but I may have missed it but how many tons of aggregates were acquired?
componenttext: First, a clarification from acquisition contribution in the quarter, both on the top line and EBIT or operating margin -- operating earnings contribution? And you may have said this, but I may have missed it but how many tons of aggregates were acquired?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the tonnage in Q2 from acquisitions was a little north of 1 million. If you look at the overall performance of our acquisitions, we're pleased with it. We had slightly higher cost that was due to 2 things. Remember, a lot of those are in Okla
componenttext: I think that the tonnage in Q2 from acquisitions was a little north of 1 million. If you look at the overall performance of our acquisitions, we're pleased with it. We had slightly higher cost that was due to 2 things. Remember, a lot of those are in Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico and Arizona. Again, the weather issue, which both dampened shipments and hurt some cost. We also recognize a couple of operations that with some capital and some modifications, we could greatly improve our long-term product offering, quality of our products and operating efficiencies. So you have those modifications in the first half of the year. I think those are starting to come -- we'll see the fruits of those probably in a quarter or 2. But overall, I think we're pleased with it. We're on track to hit the plan that we have for EBITDA of $40 million to [ph] $50 million. And I think our folks have done a good job with the integration.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Catherine, just as a reminder for everyone, we acquired not only some aggregates operations but also some good asphalt and concrete operations. So in total for the quarter, the revenue from those operations was approximately $50 million. And as they g
componenttext: And Catherine, just as a reminder for everyone, we acquired not only some aggregates operations but also some good asphalt and concrete operations. So in total for the quarter, the revenue from those operations was approximately $50 million. And as they get ramped up and as we put some additional cost, as we ramped them up because as Tom mentioned, we had some particular product hits some particular product needs, some particular customer groups. The EBITDA contribution in the quarter was about $11 million year-to-date, about $16 [ph] million from those acquisitions and generally on track, as Tom said, with our expectations.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me correct one thing. That volume was just north of 1.1 million, I misspoken.
componenttext: Let me correct one thing. That volume was just north of 1.1 million, I misspoken.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In aggregates.
componenttext: In aggregates.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of aggregates and pricing, we've always understand this is a local market. And also, pricing can vary widely according to geography and then also to mix. With that, in mind, a 2-part question. One, with pricing accelerating as the year progresses
componenttext: In terms of aggregates and pricing, we've always understand this is a local market. And also, pricing can vary widely according to geography and then also to mix. With that, in mind, a 2-part question. One, with pricing accelerating as the year progresses, how much of this is a function of higher magnitude price increases versus a greater mix of higher-priced markets finally gaining pricing?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think in all, pricing was up in all markets except Virginia, and that was really a mix issue. We have some very large shares of basin which we say is a good thing. It actually improves our profitability. We are seeing a robust price increases in most of
componenttext: I think in all, pricing was up in all markets except Virginia, and that was really a mix issue. We have some very large shares of basin which we say is a good thing. It actually improves our profitability. We are seeing a robust price increases in most of our markets. Give a little flavor on that. If you look at South Carolina, Arizona, Alabama, we saw price increases from $0.40 to $0.50 in the second quarter. In the middle of the country, which would be Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas and Illinois, we saw price increases in the $0.60 to $0.75 per ton range. And then, we saw -- in a few markets we saw, some very marked price jumps in the $0.80 -- $0.80 to $1.20 a ton range in California, Georgia and Texas. But overall, our -- it's still a local business, and our local teams are working hard to make sure we deliver value and quality and service to our customers. I think we have a lot of confidence that the pricing momentum is across all markets, and we feel good about it at this point.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Catherine, I think those are the most important points. I'll just -- we haven't had much tailwind the pricing based on geographic mix if that was your question. It's more prices across many, many markets improving.
componenttext: And Catherine, I think those are the most important points. I'll just -- we haven't had much tailwind the pricing based on geographic mix if that was your question. It's more prices across many, many markets improving.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that was -- I guess, the point I was going to follow up on. So I guess, given you haven't seen a tailwind from geographic mix and you're also flowing through cost from acquired assets, you should see, theoretically, all things equal, improving increme
componenttext: And that was -- I guess, the point I was going to follow up on. So I guess, given you haven't seen a tailwind from geographic mix and you're also flowing through cost from acquired assets, you should see, theoretically, all things equal, improving incremental margin as the year progresses?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All things being equal.
componenttext: All things being equal.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ted Grace from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ted Grace from Susquehanna.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to follow up on Trey's question. First, on the demand side. Mother nature willing, we got 3 to 4 months left in the construction season. Just to the degree you're comfortable framing out, how you're thinking about the outyear. I would to get
componenttext: I was hoping to follow up on Trey's question. First, on the demand side. Mother nature willing, we got 3 to 4 months left in the construction season. Just to the degree you're comfortable framing out, how you're thinking about the outyear. I would to get a sense of what the leading edge indicators are that you're looking at quoting activity seems early looking out in the '16, maybe quarterly business review, highlights, anything you can kind of point to on that front, would be helpful and holding?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Why don't I give a couple of numbers just to a couple of benchmarks maybe, and then Tom will add some additional market color in terms of what we're seeing from customers. All in all, we estimate that we've had about 4 million tons of aggregates shipments
componenttext: Why don't I give a couple of numbers just to a couple of benchmarks maybe, and then Tom will add some additional market color in terms of what we're seeing from customers. All in all, we estimate that we've had about 4 million tons of aggregates shipments, to start there, deferred out of the first half. You can tell that we expect to catch up, maybe about 1 million of those in the balance of the year, just by the change in the sort of indicative guidance. A lot of that will come, as you said, depend on mother nature and how long the remainder of the construction season is. And it really depends on good bit on how well many of our customers -- and Tom can comment more -- how much capacity they can add, how much work they can get done. But to get to your rough sense of the 4 million we've seen deferred on the first half, we expect to catch up about 1 million of that in the second half. That is less a function of any demand concern and is more assumption of the time and capacity of our customers to get the work completed.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think well said. I think, Ted, we have 4 months of solid season left. It will come down to constraints from contractors, going to get into the job, I mean ready-mix how fast can they get and cruise late in asphalt but overall, remember, this is wor
componenttext: Yes, I think well said. I think, Ted, we have 4 months of solid season left. It will come down to constraints from contractors, going to get into the job, I mean ready-mix how fast can they get and cruise late in asphalt but overall, remember, this is work that we see. If we don't get in the third quarter, fourth quarter, this year, it will follow in the first and second quarter next year. So it won't go away, it's just postponed. And it's very normal would we have this kind of weather to see it pushed back and when the sun comes out, we are shipping hard.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So maybe a little bit differently, if we're thinking about the comments on gradual recovery, normal recovery, would it be fair to think at least the way you're thinking internally as growth rates in end markets in '16 could approximate '15? Or anyth
componenttext: Okay. So maybe a little bit differently, if we're thinking about the comments on gradual recovery, normal recovery, would it be fair to think at least the way you're thinking internally as growth rates in end markets in '16 could approximate '15? Or anything you might share on that end?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: We haven't given any guidance obviously. We will do that at the right time. But there's nothing -- overall across what is a diversified geographic portfolio for us, we don't see anything at this point that will indicate a slowing momentum heading into nex
componenttext: We haven't given any guidance obviously. We will do that at the right time. But there's nothing -- overall across what is a diversified geographic portfolio for us, we don't see anything at this point that will indicate a slowing momentum heading into next year. And there's always issues -- state-specific issues, right, but across the portfolio in total. Although we're not giving guidance, we don't see a decline in momentum.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: The second one clarification, could you give us a bridge on EBITDA kind of 2Q '14 to 2Q '15, just another pricing tailwind volumes to tailwind, energy to tailwinds, acquisitions to tailwinds, can you just maybe help bridge as certain understand headwinds
componenttext: The second one clarification, could you give us a bridge on EBITDA kind of 2Q '14 to 2Q '15, just another pricing tailwind volumes to tailwind, energy to tailwinds, acquisitions to tailwinds, can you just maybe help bridge as certain understand headwinds more gradually, I remember, labor was up, SG&A, just a bridge there would be great. And I'll get back in queue.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, I think the only headwind that we saw was probably cost in the quarter with slightly higher, labor cost and imagined R&M were up. The labor peace weather cause inefficiencies, and the stone operation actually ready-mix and asphalt also. So whether
componenttext: Really, I think the only headwind that we saw was probably cost in the quarter with slightly higher, labor cost and imagined R&M were up. The labor peace weather cause inefficiencies, and the stone operation actually ready-mix and asphalt also. So whether effective labor and also affected the rest of our operating efficiencies and tons per gallon of fuel and electrical power. We're also beginning to run our plants with increased demand. We're starting to run our plants a little harder and longer. If you start to do this, if you'd start to find a few weak spot and equipment. We also took the opportunity in the second quarter when we were down to do repairs. So while in cost was up. But if you look at it from a longer-term view, our year-to-date cost is down about $0.10. On a same-store basis, it's down $0.16. trailing 12 months, it's down $0.22, but the disciplines in operating efficiencies and operating cost is something that everybody focuses on every day, it's somebody's just got a stay on top of will get away. So I think our people are very focused on things they control and the efficiencies in those operations. So the tailwind, I guess, the headwind that I saw in the quarter was really one of cost and it was a mix of or and weather-related inefficiencies.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Ted, if it helps, on the gross profit line, we basically, as Tom described, it would be got awash between the cost increases. So for a per unit basis, that was the cost basis we wash in the gross profit line. So really, the biggest bridge, of course,
componenttext: And Ted, if it helps, on the gross profit line, we basically, as Tom described, it would be got awash between the cost increases. So for a per unit basis, that was the cost basis we wash in the gross profit line. So really, the biggest bridge, of course, gets back volume. And again if we had 4 million tons deferred out of the first half of aggregates, we'd estimate that's about a $35 million impact or so, plus or minus, at the EBITDA line. But the biggest factor in the quarter unit cost may be awash well volumes, of course, as headwind, if that's helpful.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Armstrong from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Armstrong from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the -- follow-up on the asphalt segment. How much of the incremental operating margin was impacted due to oil prices and [indiscernible] was a significant part of that? Do believe that you have to pass on some of that as the year p
componenttext: My first question is on the -- follow-up on the asphalt segment. How much of the incremental operating margin was impacted due to oil prices and [indiscernible] was a significant part of that? Do believe that you have to pass on some of that as the year progresses? Or will you be able to maintain those margin levels for the remainder of the year?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: There were definitely tailwinds with oil, but I think you have to look at -- to try to separate that out when you run in over 50 asphalt plants across the whole Southwest is really difficult to do. It's really a matter of managing the uses of oil with rec
componenttext: There were definitely tailwinds with oil, but I think you have to look at -- to try to separate that out when you run in over 50 asphalt plants across the whole Southwest is really difficult to do. It's really a matter of managing the uses of oil with recycled asphalt products, recycled shingles, each mix design maximizing it out and maximizing operating efficiencies and the cost of operations, along with sales and service and value and price. So I think that to try to separate that out is pretty tough to do. So as far as getting that back, getting back any savings on oil, you don't see -- we don't see that those headwinds at this point. We don't know that for sure. But I think that right now, we're pretty confident in our ability to manage the combination of customer service material margin operating cost and continue what we're doing today.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the aggregate segment. As we come to the back half of the year, have the regions in which you're seeing pricing momentum changed from what you saw in the first half of the year? And can you detail that a little bit more for us?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the aggregate segment. As we come to the back half of the year, have the regions in which you're seeing pricing momentum changed from what you saw in the first half of the year? And can you detail that a little bit more for us?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that anything's changed as far as the momentum we've seen in the pricing. Obviously, the more mature markets in the recovery -- the markets of more mature recovery, the cost price lags volume or seen the biggest jump in pricing. But overall,
componenttext: I don't know that anything's changed as far as the momentum we've seen in the pricing. Obviously, the more mature markets in the recovery -- the markets of more mature recovery, the cost price lags volume or seen the biggest jump in pricing. But overall, I don't -- I think the trend is pretty steady. I think we'll continue -- not only is it steady, but it will continue to improve as we go forward. And as we said earlier, we'll be back-half-loaded with the price improvement.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And substantially across markets, but I think, back on what Tom said, I think all of our states saw pricing increase on the same-store basis at some level. So a trend, if we went back a few quarters, would be that it's broadening. The rate is very substan
componenttext: And substantially across markets, but I think, back on what Tom said, I think all of our states saw pricing increase on the same-store basis at some level. So a trend, if we went back a few quarters, would be that it's broadening. The rate is very substantial across states, but the trend would be that it's broadening.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Martinez from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Martinez from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's actually, in for Tim didn't today. You made some pretty universally positive comments in terms of demand trends. I just wanted to see what's you're seeing leakage because just from a weaker energy market in any of your customers, maybe in energy proj
componenttext: It's actually, in for Tim didn't today. You made some pretty universally positive comments in terms of demand trends. I just wanted to see what's you're seeing leakage because just from a weaker energy market in any of your customers, maybe in energy projects, things like that.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you look at the energy projects along the coast, the LNG projects, refinery projects, we're actually, seeing that to continue to pick up. My guess is we'll ship over 2 million tons to that segment on the coast. Remember, the reason why we're so advanta
componenttext: If you look at the energy projects along the coast, the LNG projects, refinery projects, we're actually, seeing that to continue to pick up. My guess is we'll ship over 2 million tons to that segment on the coast. Remember, the reason why we're so advantaged with our blue water delivery is those projects require big volumes of water for a short amount of time. So if you put that over 2 million and 2.5 million this year, I will tell you that next year, what we would know right now, this is what we probably under contract, we'd just be south of 2 million, it's probably on the drawing board, another 8 million tons in projects that are out there that haven't bid, still in permitting or plan process. So no slowdown in the energy projects along the coast.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then in terms of the pricing momentum you're talking about in the second half, many from price hikes that you've already implemented and announced in the first half? Or is some of that assumed the additional price hikes in the second half as we
componenttext: Great. And then in terms of the pricing momentum you're talking about in the second half, many from price hikes that you've already implemented and announced in the first half? Or is some of that assumed the additional price hikes in the second half as well?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we always say, our pricing is across dozens of markets. So each one's individual and then you've got -- within those markets, you have a fixed plants where you got price increases in all the different times of the year. And then you got quoting work wh
componenttext: As we always say, our pricing is across dozens of markets. So each one's individual and then you've got -- within those markets, you have a fixed plants where you got price increases in all the different times of the year. And then you got quoting work which you are pressing price with each quote each week. So it is a combination of what we've secured pricing that we'll quote higher in the second half and that announced price increases in the second half, and then you also working off work. So you got to put all that into the mix. And again, you've got to aggregate all those pricing movements across all those markets.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on diesel. You had a nice benefit here in the second quarter. Coming into the beginning of the year, we thought there could be some potential upside because of diesel savings. Just wondering how you think about diesel cost in the back ha
componenttext: First question is on diesel. You had a nice benefit here in the second quarter. Coming into the beginning of the year, we thought there could be some potential upside because of diesel savings. Just wondering how you think about diesel cost in the back half of the year as it relates to your overall EBITDA guidance?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, if you look at our guidance, this goes into individual operations. So there is different diesel savings built in from the ground-up perspective in the second half of the year. There's also -- built through that labor cost, the finance cost, and o
componenttext: I think, if you look at our guidance, this goes into individual operations. So there is different diesel savings built in from the ground-up perspective in the second half of the year. There's also -- built through that labor cost, the finance cost, and operating parts supplies. So I think if you put that all together, if you look at our guidance, we do have diesel built into it.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess it's fair to assume that some of the other cost just mentioned will partially offset.
componenttext: I guess it's fair to assume that some of the other cost just mentioned will partially offset.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's the right way to think about it, Garik. I don't know if we're the world's best at predicting future diesel prices and those kinds of things. We will begin to comp over, if you will, longer lower cost as we get into the third and fourth quar
componenttext: I think that's the right way to think about it, Garik. I don't know if we're the world's best at predicting future diesel prices and those kinds of things. We will begin to comp over, if you will, longer lower cost as we get into the third and fourth quarter. So I think you summed it up well which is we would expect it to continue to manage improving men margins in the second half in total. And underneath, that's a mix of several factors, probably a little help from diesel costs, probably a little bit higher repair and maintenance cost than we've seen in the past.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just shifting to capital allocation, you mentioned, I think it was $30 million or so to update your Panamax fleet. Just wondering if this is in relation to any sort of capacity addition that you're undergoing in the Cancun facility and if we should antici
componenttext: Just shifting to capital allocation, you mentioned, I think it was $30 million or so to update your Panamax fleet. Just wondering if this is in relation to any sort of capacity addition that you're undergoing in the Cancun facility and if we should anticipate increased volumes coming out for your long-haul operations.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: These are specific replacements for the ships that we started our operations with. So those ships are some 30 years old. It's time for them to retire for all kinds of reasons. Now what we will get in the new ships is the technology. We'll have a little mo
componenttext: These are specific replacements for the ships that we started our operations with. So those ships are some 30 years old. It's time for them to retire for all kinds of reasons. Now what we will get in the new ships is the technology. We'll have a little more payload. We'll have much better fuel efficiencies and probably a little better speed out of those ships so we'll get better efficiencies. But the bottom line of that is ships are replacements.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, I'll ask the highway question. sounded very optimistic in your prepared remarks around the new Highway Bill. Just wondering, it's early but if you could provide some thoughts on -- we do get a multiyear bill towards the end of the year, but as w
componenttext: And then, I'll ask the highway question. sounded very optimistic in your prepared remarks around the new Highway Bill. Just wondering, it's early but if you could provide some thoughts on -- we do get a multiyear bill towards the end of the year, but as we look at a volume opportunity would that imply for aggregates demand moving forward?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we put a number to that because it's got so many unknowns in that bill and what does it mean. We have not at this point. The one thing I will say is that a long-term bill, even at the funding that we have today is a good thing for us, be
componenttext: I don't know that we put a number to that because it's got so many unknowns in that bill and what does it mean. We have not at this point. The one thing I will say is that a long-term bill, even at the funding that we have today is a good thing for us, because it gives securities to those states -- so we've got a number of states that are pushing back the jobs because they don't have securities, they going to get paid by federal government. So the worst case if we get flat funding with a long-term bill, we look at it as a very good thing. At the same time, we've got a number of states, which have already substantially increased their funding, and we have a number of the key states to us, including California, which are looking at recognize they have to increase their funding, and they're taking steps towards that. So overall, with the steps the taking and Congress that the House is taking, we're pleased with it, we've got high hopes for it, we think we've got a lot of momentum and on top of that, you've got the momentum of improving state funding or the recognition the state funding has to increase.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to continue the discussion, regulatory side, California is in session or legislation is in instead session of potentially increasing state Highway funding. How optimistic are you that something goes through? And what's your sense on where the process
componenttext: Just to continue the discussion, regulatory side, California is in session or legislation is in instead session of potentially increasing state Highway funding. How optimistic are you that something goes through? And what's your sense on where the process stands now?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little background -- yes, let me give you a little background on California. Their highway bill right now is at about $11 billion annually. If things stays status quo, they'd cut that to 5% to about $10.5 billion. They recognize that the
componenttext: Let me give you a little background -- yes, let me give you a little background on California. Their highway bill right now is at about $11 billion annually. If things stays status quo, they'd cut that to 5% to about $10.5 billion. They recognize that they have to take steps to not only keep that whole but to improve it. Their Senate Bill 16, which is out there right now, which will improve it or increase it by another $3 billion, it's too early to give you a guess on that at this point or prediction. I think the good thing is they recognize that they have a shortfall, they going to have to address it and they've taken steps So the leading place of this roads, California sure does. So they do recognize, and the leadership there is taking steps to improve it.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sorry. And what's your of timing, expected to play out?
componenttext: Sorry. And what's your of timing, expected to play out?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's too early to tell. I would tell you a guess at this point.
componenttext: I think it's too early to tell. I would tell you a guess at this point.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

Can you just don't listen to the think about stripping cost over the next couple of years, how much are you changing mine plants as business picking up?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we're changing mine plants with the mine plant is really based on the long-term operations of the quarry. Obviously, as volume grows up, it's up to strip board just because you have your producing more tons. I think other times is we are
componenttext: I don't know that we're changing mine plants with the mine plant is really based on the long-term operations of the quarry. Obviously, as volume grows up, it's up to strip board just because you have your producing more tons. I think other times is we are opportunistic when we strip. So maybe when we're not running an operation for whatever reason, accrued equipment and go strip because it's just good sense and good use of cost. But overall, I don't see pricing having an impact, volume obviously does because you have to strip more with all volume. And in each individual mine, it's based on what that operation has to do for the long term. I mean we're running this operations for decades, now a few years, so stripping is a big part of the long-term planning.
