headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Vulcan Materials Company Second Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference call coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the call over to your host, Mr. Mark Warren, Director of Investo
componenttext: Welcome to the Vulcan Materials Company Second Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Kayla, and I will be your conference call coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] And now I'd like to turn the call over to your host, Mr. Mark Warren, Director of Investor Relations for Vulcan Materials. Mr. Warren, you may begin.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kayla. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for your interest in Vulcan Materials Company. Joining me today for this call are Tom Hill, President and CEO; and John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. Plea
componenttext:
Thank you, Kayla. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for your interest in Vulcan Materials Company. Joining me today for this call are Tom Hill, President and CEO; and John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. Please note a slide presentation will accompany the prepared remarks by management and is available via the webcast. A copy of this presentation as well as a replay of the conference call will be available following the conclusion of this call at the company's website.
Before we begin, I refer you to Slide 2 of our presentation regarding forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Descriptions of these are detailed in the company's SEC reports, including our most recent report on Form 10-K.
In addition, during this call, management will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measures. You can find the reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measure and other related information in our earnings release and at the end of this presentation.
Now I'd like turn the call over to Vulcan's Chief Executive Officer, Tom Hill. Tom?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and thanks to all of you for joining us today. Let me begin by thanking our employees for their outstanding performance in the second quarter. As you all know, weather conditions were unusually bad during the quarter with prolonged wet we
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and thanks to all of you for joining us today. Let me begin by thanking our employees for their outstanding performance in the second quarter. As you all know, weather conditions were unusually bad during the quarter with prolonged wet weather and serious flooding impeding construction activity in many parts of the U.S. In spite of these challenges, we operated safely, served our customers well and delivered strong results. The metrics and slides we'll talk about today are largely the same as in prior quarters. We're on track to have a very good year. Our focus hasn't changed and neither has our optimism regarding continued performance improvement. Construction activity and materials demand continue to recover. Pricing momentum is accelerating, and our employees are doing a really good job converting incremental revenues into incremental profits.
Despite the bad weather in many of our markets, we enjoyed strong earnings growth and margin expansion on higher revenues, underscoring our confidence in our full year outlook. With improving market conditions and our focus on profit improvements, both pricing and margins continue to expand. As you can see on Slide 4, adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.66 per diluted share, an increase of $0.30 from the prior year. Although overall average shipments were lower than expected due to weather, we continue to see expanding gross profit margins and expanding EBITDA margins. As you can see, overall gross profit margins increased by more than 450 basis points. These strong margins were supported by robust pricing momentum. We experienced strong earnings growth in aggregates and in each of our non-aggregates segment. This was also accompanied by declining SAG cost as a percent of sales. In spite of the weather challenges, our people did an outstanding job taking incremental revenue to the bottom line. As we noted before, our local teams across our footprint are doing a great job managing sales and production mix along with pricing. At the same time, we continue to reap the benefits of improving operating efficiencies and resulting leverage.
Total gross profit increased 34%, and adjusted EBITDA was up 33%. Same-store shipments increased 5% and same-store pricing increased over 6%, with strong pricing momentum across most markets. Our profitability continue to improve significantly, whether measured by margin percentage or per-unit profit.
Now let's look at the monthly trend of our aggregates shipments and the impact of weather on Slide 5. Rain in the second quarter reduced the number of available shipping days in key markets, and it certainly postponed shipments. Slide 5 shows the year-over-year change in monthly shipments. You can see the impact of rain on shipments in April and May, up only 5% and 2% on a same-store basis. In April, it was pervasive across most markets with above average rainfall in 13 of our states. In May, severe wet weather affected plant operations and construction activity in Arizona, Illinois, Louisiana, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas. In June, with the important exceptions of Illinois and Virginia, the weather allowed for more normal days of construction activity, and shipments were robust revealing again the momentum in demand.
The map on Slide 6 shows a breakdown of 5% growth in aggregates shipments across the country on a same-store basis. Even with all the wet weather, the vast majority of our states experienced healthy growth. Momentum in shipments continued with solid growth in key states. Same-store shipments in Florida, Georgia, Illinois, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas and Virginia saw shipments growth ranging from 5% to 11%. Although California volumes were down 3% due to several large projects that have been delayed until the second half of the year, our full year outlook for shipments growth in California remains unchanged, and our view and that of our customers, this is demand deferred, not lost.
I'd like to draw your attention to Slide 7, aggregates pricing. As we discussed before, pricing growth tends to lag volume growth. We experienced in the second quarter the initial stages of this improving pricing momentum. We are pleased with a nice increase in freight-adjusted aggregates price of 6.4% in the second quarter, and we fully expect to see pricing accelerate. This is supported by the confidence we see in our customers' view of the markets. We had 9 major markets where price increases range from $0.60 to $1.20 and another 3 approaching the $0.50 range. In limited instances where we didn't see such robust pricing, it was a function of product mix. We experienced much larger shipments of base and fines on new construction and large projects, especially in Virginia and North Carolina. Growing volume in base and fines may detract from price but improves overall profitability. Prices will escalate throughout the year as new prices are initiated and as we finish older jobs. At this point, we also expect second half price increases to exceed 8%. Pricing momentum for Vulcan will continue. We are focused on earning a good return on the significant investments that we in this industry make on behalf of our customers.
We talk a lot about the 3 profit drivers that are expanding our margins and profits because they're important. On Slide 8, you can see that our second quarter and trailing 12-month gross profit per ton increased 21% and 23%, respectively. So in the quarter, price was up $0.71 per ton, but gross profit margin was up $0.76 per ton. Our sales and operations teams continue to do an outstanding job turning demand into higher profitability. Nobody in the business does a better job of managing the combination of price, operating efficiencies, volume and products. We continue to be excited about the ongoing very positive trend in unit margin expansion for Vulcan. It's not a new story.
As you can see on Slide 9, we have now seen 8 consecutive quarters of expanding unit margin. Since our volumes began to grow in the second half of 2013, our gross profit per ton has increased sharply, and we are now seeing the additional benefits of strong and ongoing improvement in pricing. Our unit profitability is higher than when these operations were producing twice the volume.
In the most recent quarter, we saw an increase in repair and maintenance and labor cost. This is not surprising. Growing volumes are requiring us to run operations longer, resulting in more repairs, and wet weather negatively impacts labor efficiencies. This is something that we will be managing very carefully even as we see pricing momentum and continued unit margin expansion that more than offsets these costs. Even though we are still in the early stages of recovery, we are very pleased with this momentum. Demand for our products continues to escalate, and I'm extremely proud of the way our people are focused on unit margin growth.
Slide 10 shows our incremental margin performance in our aggregates segment. Incremental gross profit margin for the second quarter was 74%, excluding the impact of acquisitions completed during 2014. Aggregates gross profit grew by $44 million on incremental freight-adjusted revenues of $59 million. Including the impact of acquisitions, the incremental margin was 61%, with the gross margin on those revenues impacted by acquisition accounting and weather. Since quarterly figures can be distorted by seasonality or onetime cost, we also present the same metric calculated on a trailing 12-month basis. For the trailing 12 months that ended this quarter, incremental gross profit margin was 72%, adjusted for the same acquisitions. Aggregates gross profit increased approximately $157 million on incremental revenues of $219 million. Given our strategic focus on the aggregates business, our ability to take that revenue to the bottom line is a big advantage to Vulcan as volumes continue to recover. With that, I will now turn the call over to John for additional comments regarding our earnings performance and outlook for the remainder of the year. John?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll start with Slide 11, which effectively serves as the capstone to many of the metrics and trends Tom just highlighted. On this slide, we summarized the improvement in our aggregates segment results since the recovery and volumes began in
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll start with Slide 11, which effectively serves as the capstone to many of the metrics and trends Tom just highlighted. On this slide, we summarized the improvement in our aggregates segment results since the recovery and volumes began in the second half of 2013. Before the recovery began, our annualized aggregates volumes troughed at 140 million tons. That was 2 years ago. As of the quarter just ended, our trailing 12-month shipments are 170 million tons. So we've added 30 million tons of aggregates shipments on an annualized basis. This gain reflects a sustained early recovery but remains well below the shipments we'd expect under normal demand conditions.
Now importantly, we've been able to increase segment gross profit by just over $260 million during this 2-year period, with per ton gross profit increasing more than $1 or over 40%. Certainly, a central part of our strategic and operational focus remains on sustaining these trends and fully capitalizing on the continued recovery toward normal levels of demand for the materials we provide.
Now let me turn to Slide 12 to briefly look at our asphalt and concrete segment results for the quarter. These businesses also performed well in the quarter, especially given weather-related challenges in Texas, Virginia, Arizona and New Mexico. Our local management of these operations continues to service customers well while also effectively managing material margins. And segment results for both asphalt and concrete have benefited from recent transactions that better focus our asset portfolio. Year-to-date, the gross profit from these businesses has exceeded plan despite weather-related challenges.
Looking at the asphalt segment, you see the gross profit for the quarter was approximately $21 million, a year-over-year improvement of $12 million, driven by strong cost disciplines and margin management as well as the impact of acquired operations. On a same-store basis, asphalt volumes increased 8% from the prior year and unit profitability increased sharply. And looking at the concrete segment, you see second quarter gross profit was approximately $5 million compared to $3 million in the prior year, as margin improvements helped offset the impact of work deferred due to weather including a record wet June in the Virginia, Maryland area where we have our largest concrete operations.
Moving now to capital allocation. Slide 13 highlights certain second quarter actions and updates consistent with our previously communicated capital allocation priorities and capital structure goals. These priorities and goals have not changed, and we continue to work diligently against them. First, we continue to make the CapEx investments necessary to sustain the long-term value of our franchise and to meet our customers' rising requirements. Our core CapEx spending for the year remains in line with prior communications at approximately $250 million. In addition, we've committed to replace to 2 of our 3 Panamax-class ships which transport product from our high-volume quarry in Mexico. The vessels being replaced have over 30 years of service each, and the advantages of our bluewater distribution network usually merit the investment. We expect progress payments on the construction of the new ships to be approximately $36 million this year, with another $85 million spread across 2016 and 2017.
Next, we intend to maintain our financial strength and flexibility at all parts of the cycle. Consistent with this goal, we've now completed the major components of the refinancing plan outlined during our February Investor Day and discussed at length during our first quarter call. These accomplishments include extending maturities on approximately $620 million of debt, otherwise due over the next 5 years; establishing a new $750 million unsecured credit facility; and lowering our average weighted or lower -- lowering our weighted average interest rate. Our second quarter results include $45 million or $0.24 per diluted share of expense associated with this activity. In addition, we took steps in the second quarter to streamline our corporate legal entity structure. These actions improve our flexibility and reduce certain administrative burdens, for example, significantly reducing the number of state income tax filings we prepare. We expect another outcome to be a more appropriate and efficient allocation of interest expense and overall taxable income across the states in which we operate. We currently anticipate a $3 million to $5 million reduction in the annual state tax expense or an approximately 100 basis point reduction in our overall effective tax rate for 2015. In addition, we may be able to utilize over time all or a portion of approximately $60 million in state-level NOLs, which may otherwise have expired unused. Next, we continue to pursue bolt-on acquisitions. During the second quarter, for example, we acquired 3 aggregates facilities and 7 ready-mix operations in Arizona and New Mexico for approximately $21 million, complementing our existing positions in those markets. The pipeline of bolt-on acquisitions opportunities remains active, but we will remain a disciplined buyer and, as such, the number, size and timing of future transactions remains difficult to predict. As our performance improves, so does our capacity to return capital to shareholders. We continue to believe that we will have the ability to both reinvest for growth and return capital to shareholders as the recovery to a normal demand unfolds.
Now let me take a couple of -- now let me make a couple of comments about end markets and then our outlook for the balance of 2015 before handing the call back to Tom for some closing remarks and Q&A. As Tom noted earlier and as you can see reflected in our Q2 results, construction activity continues to recover in Vulcan-served markets, although it remains far below long-term trend levels. Looking through the weather and the noise in Congress, we and our customers continue to see gradually improving demand in each of the major end markets we serve. Shipping rates on clear days underscore recovery demand across geographies and across end users. With few exceptions, construction activity in our markets remains well below long-term true cycle trends, but the recovery continues. That would be the main message here.
Now to touch briefly on some of the underlying trends in private and public construction. With respect to private demand, we continue to see manufacturing and other industrial-related projects contributing to significant nonresidential construction growth. And as you probably know, housing starts, despite month-to-month volatility, continue to trend upward across most Vulcan-served markets. On the public side, large projects have driven recent strength in highway awards. State and local-level funding initiatives support continued growth in road and other infrastructure spending, particularly in the intermediate term. At the federal level, we remain optimistic that a multiyear bill may pass sometime in the fall. Tom will have more to say on this in a moment, but the need for a meaningful multiyear program is understood on both sides of the aisle, and recent developments have been well covered in the press. So to the extent we harbor modest concerns were regarding our full year 2015 volumes relative to plan, they primarily relate back to first half weather and the capacity of our customers to complete deferred work during the remainder of the available construction season. In several of our markets, key customers find themselves 6 or more weeks behind on scheduled work, and they short term challenges in adding the capacity required to catch up. In addition, the extension into the fall of uncertainty regarding the Federal Highway Program may impact the start date and timing of shipments to certain road infrastructure projects. Again, the marginal risk we see to 2015 shipments is one of timing and potential deferral into 2016.
Now I'll turn it briefly to Slide 15 and our outlook for the balance of the year. As noted in our earnings release, our full year EBITDA guidance range remains unchanged at $775 million to $825 million, this despite the weather-related challenges of the first half of the year. In short, we anticipate better-than-expected pricing and margin momentum to offset a potential shortfall in 2015 shipments relative to plan. The continued improvement in pricing and unit margins matches our strategic focus and bodes very well for the longer-term performance and value of our franchise. I'll now touch on certain of the modest adjustments we've made to assumptions underlying our full year EBITDA guidance. As stated previously, please view these figures as indicative midpoints of our range of expectations. We want to give you a good feel for how we see the business performing, but we don't want to convey a false sense of precision regarding each and every metric. With respect to aggregates shipments, we reduced our midpoint expectations for the year from 180 million tons to 177 million tons. This change reflects the challenges many of our customer face as they try to catch up with deferred work, the longer-than-expected ramp-ups in production at certain of our acquired operations and marginally higher uncertainty regarding start dates and shipping pace for certain large projects. Our fundamental view of a continued gradual recovery in demand remains unchanged. With regard to aggregates pricing, we've raised our midpoint expectation for year-on-year growth from 6% to 7%. As Tom noted, pricing fundamentals are strong and getting stronger in many markets. We expect the rate of improvement in the second half to exceed that of the first half. At this point, we would expect these pricing trends to continue into 2016. Due to potential shortfall in 2015 shipments volumes, we slightly reduced our midpoint expectation for aggregates segment gross profit. We expect the rate in which incremental freight-adjusted revenues flow through to incremental gross profit to remain roughly in line with recent trailing 12-month trends. Our asphalt and concrete segments have also seen rising profitability, both on a same-store basis and as a result of recent acquisition, divestiture and swap activity. As a result, we raised our midpoint expectation for full year gross profit from these segments from $70 million to $80 million. Our expectations for SAG, DD&A and core CapEx remain largely unchanged. All in all, our businesses enjoy strong momentum in volumes, pricing, margins and capital productivity. Our teams are executing well, serving our customers well and focusing on what they could control. The underlying fundamentals of our business remain very exciting. With that, I will turn the call back over to Tom. Tom?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. As John stated, we are confident in our full year outlook. We are pleased with our team's performance in the second quarter despite the challenges of extreme weather. Our markets continue to improve in each market segment and across most of
componenttext: Thanks, John. As John stated, we are confident in our full year outlook. We are pleased with our team's performance in the second quarter despite the challenges of extreme weather. Our markets continue to improve in each market segment and across most of our geographic footprint. This growing demand is causing price momentum to pick up robustly, which is clearly demonstrated in the second quarter results. I am confident in our employees' ability to execute on the disciplined operating efficiencies to drive cost control and customer service that drives value and price, all of which improve our unit profitability. We are very proud of our employees' hard work and dedication. We are also pleased with the level of activity on the Highway bill in Congress over the last 2 weeks. This culminated on July 30 and as soon as passage of a new 6-year bill to drive that. The Senate house, also last week, passed a 3-month extension to MAP-21, the current bill. This will allow the House time to complete work on its version of the new bill. House and Senate leadership stated their intention to go to conference with their respective bills and sending new multiyear bill to the President for his signature on the poll. This gathered momentum in Congress to address federal highway investments coupled with growing initiatives to improve roads in many states is very encouraging. We, along with many other transportation stakeholders, will continue to press for additional much-needed investments in America's aging infrastructure. As we look forward to the balance of 2015 and into 2016, we're excited about the accelerated momentum in demand and pricing, and the improving execution by our employees. They are finding new ways to improve this company and our profitability every day. Now if the operator will give the required instructions, we'll be happy to respond to your questions.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Trey Grooms from Stephens.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Trey Grooms from Stephens.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Tom, you mentioned accelerating demand, and I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color around what you're seeing in specific geographic markets now that the weather has started to cooperate, if you can kind of give us an idea more specif
componenttext: Tom, you mentioned accelerating demand, and I was wondering if you could give us a little bit more color around what you're seeing in specific geographic markets now that the weather has started to cooperate, if you can kind of give us an idea more specifically there.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, we're seeing growth in all market segments, as I stated, and in the vast majority of our geography. About half of our individual markets, we think will experience double-digit growth this year. So all across-the-board, we're seeing strong de
componenttext: Yes. Overall, we're seeing growth in all market segments, as I stated, and in the vast majority of our geography. About half of our individual markets, we think will experience double-digit growth this year. So all across-the-board, we're seeing strong demand. Texas is probably the hottest market we have. Even with the impact of weather, we saw same-store shipments volume, up 8% in Texas. Florida continues to be extremely healthy. I think we were up some-11% in Florida for the quarter. Georgia, very, very healthy. And actually, Georgia got hit a little bit with weather, but that demand just pushed back. And every time the sun comes out in Georgia, we're shipping very strongly. So overall, everything is -- the vast majority of the markets are going well. If there is a spot that was a little behind the rest of the country, I'd say it was Alabama, Mississippi, that area. As I stated, California, while the second quarter was a little slow because we had some jobs pushed back, and it may be a little bit behind the rest of the country, overall, its demand growth is steady.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And you guys have been putting up some really good incrementals, great unit margins continuing to improve. Just wondering, at what point -- I know John mentioned, again, kind of touched on the mid-cycle demand expectation of 250 million tons
componenttext: Okay. Great. And you guys have been putting up some really good incrementals, great unit margins continuing to improve. Just wondering, at what point -- I know John mentioned, again, kind of touched on the mid-cycle demand expectation of 250 million tons or so. At what point in this recovery coming off of 170 LTM tons do we start to see these incremental start to slow down some or subside a little bit and maybe the unit margins start to kind of slow with the growth there or improvement?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think as we talked about, these same operations in the peak would've done 300 million tons. We're sitting, and as we said, 177 so -- and we said normal is 255, so we've got a long ways to go before we start looking at any reduction in incremental revenu
componenttext: I think as we talked about, these same operations in the peak would've done 300 million tons. We're sitting, and as we said, 177 so -- and we said normal is 255, so we've got a long ways to go before we start looking at any reduction in incremental revenue -- in incremental returns. .

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Trey, all I would add is that, while it appears we're seeing some rising costs -- some trends in rising costs, we're able to manage those so far. You see that on our margin performance. Our operator to local teams do a fantastic job. We don't see any imme
componenttext: Trey, all I would add is that, while it appears we're seeing some rising costs -- some trends in rising costs, we're able to manage those so far. You see that on our margin performance. Our operator to local teams do a fantastic job. We don't see any immediate or near-term change in recent trajectory, but I would reiterate that our more long-term through the cycle commentary and guidance on flow-throughs is more in the order of 60% than the recent trends you've seen. But that said, don't take that as a signal that we expect some imminent decline in recent performance.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then, on asphalt, very strong. The incrementals and the margins there are tracking well above our expectations. Is there anything going on in the quarter there? Do you expect these trends to continue in asphalt? And I'll turn it over.
componenttext: Understood. And then, on asphalt, very strong. The incrementals and the margins there are tracking well above our expectations. Is there anything going on in the quarter there? Do you expect these trends to continue in asphalt? And I'll turn it over.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. The asphalt segment was up some-$12 million. $9 million of that was on without the same-store basis, $3 million was the acquisitions. So we're pleased -- you got to remember that asphalt, a lot of that asphalt is in Texas, New Mexico and Arizona, so
componenttext: Yes. The asphalt segment was up some-$12 million. $9 million of that was on without the same-store basis, $3 million was the acquisitions. So we're pleased -- you got to remember that asphalt, a lot of that asphalt is in Texas, New Mexico and Arizona, so they did have the headwinds of weather. So we're very pleased with our operating group being able to deliver value to our customers, manage material margins and operating costs and give customer service with all that rain. That's tough to do. On top of that, the $3 million improvement from the recent acquisitions, we believe that that's a sign those have been integrated well and quickly. In that, we got a lot of talent, that we're glad to add to the team. So both the same-store and the acquisitions, we're pleased with the performance. I don't see anything in this that would slow that down at this point.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Trey and for others, I think with that, I'll just remind folks newer to our business that we tend to earn pretty good returns on capital in the asphalt segment through the cycle and over time, so we're pleased with those investments.
componenttext: And Trey and for others, I think with that, I'll just remind folks newer to our business that we tend to earn pretty good returns on capital in the asphalt segment through the cycle and over time, so we're pleased with those investments.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson Research Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Kathryn Thompson from Thompson Research Group.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First is a clarification from acquisition contribution in the quarter, both on the top line and EBIT or operating margin -- operating earnings contribution. And then you may have said this, but I may have missed it, but how many tons of aggregates were ac
componenttext: First is a clarification from acquisition contribution in the quarter, both on the top line and EBIT or operating margin -- operating earnings contribution. And then you may have said this, but I may have missed it, but how many tons of aggregates were acquired?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that the tonnage in Q2 from acquisitions was a little north of 1 million. If you look at the overall performance of our acquisitions, we're pleased with it. We had slightly higher cost that was due to 2 things. Remember, a lot of those are in Okla
componenttext: I think that the tonnage in Q2 from acquisitions was a little north of 1 million. If you look at the overall performance of our acquisitions, we're pleased with it. We had slightly higher cost that was due to 2 things. Remember, a lot of those are in Oklahoma, Texas, New Mexico and Arizona. Again, the weather issue, which both dampened shipments and hurt us on cost. We also recognize in a couple of operations that with some capital and some modifications, we could greatly improve our long-term product offering, quality of our products and operating efficiencies. So you had those modifications in the first half of the year. I think those are starting to come -- we'll see the fruits of those probably in a quarter or 2. But overall, I think we're pleased with it. We're on track to hit the plan that we have for EBITDA of $40 million to $50 million. And I think my folks have done a good job with the integration.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Kathryn, just as a reminder for everyone, we acquired not only some aggregates operations but also some good asphalt and concrete operations. So in total for the quarter, the revenue from those operations was approximately $50 million. And as they get
componenttext: And Kathryn, just as a reminder for everyone, we acquired not only some aggregates operations but also some good asphalt and concrete operations. So in total for the quarter, the revenue from those operations was approximately $50 million. And as they get ramped up and as we put some additional cost into them as we ramp them up and, as Tom mentioned, hit some particular product needs or particular customer groups, the EBITDA contribution in the quarter was about $11 million year-to-date, about $16 million from those acquisitions and generally on track, as Tom said, with our expectations.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me correct one thing. That volume was just north of 1.4 million, I misspoken, sorry.
componenttext: Let me correct one thing. That volume was just north of 1.4 million, I misspoken, sorry.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In aggregates.
componenttext: In aggregates.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: In aggregates, yes.
componenttext: In aggregates, yes.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Helpful color on that. Just in terms of aggregates pricing, we always understand this is a local market and it's also -- pricing can vary widely according to geography and then also to mix. With that in mind, 2-part question. One, with pricing acceleratin
componenttext: Helpful color on that. Just in terms of aggregates pricing, we always understand this is a local market and it's also -- pricing can vary widely according to geography and then also to mix. With that in mind, 2-part question. One, with pricing accelerating as the year progresses, how much of this is a function of higher magnitude price increases versus a greater mix of higher-priced markets finally gaining pricing?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think in all -- pricing was up in all markets except Virginia, and that was really a mix issue. We had some very large sales of base and fines which, as we say, is a good thing. We like that. It actually improves our profitability. We are seeing robust
componenttext: I think in all -- pricing was up in all markets except Virginia, and that was really a mix issue. We had some very large sales of base and fines which, as we say, is a good thing. We like that. It actually improves our profitability. We are seeing robust price increases in most of our markets. I'd give you a little flavor on that. If you look at South Carolina, Arizona, Alabama, we saw price increases from $0.40 to $0.50 in the second quarter. In the middle of the country, which would be Tennessee, Kentucky, Arkansas and Illinois, we saw price increases in the $0.60 to $0.75 per ton range. And then, we saw -- in a few markets we saw, some very marked price jumps in the $0.80 -- $0.80 to $1.20 a ton range in California, Florida, Georgia and Texas. But overall, our -- it's still a local business, and our local teams are working hard to make sure we deliver value and quality and service to our customers. I think we have a lot of confidence that the pricing momentum is across all markets, and we feel good about it at this point.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Kathryn, I think those are the most important points. I just -- we haven't had much tailwind to pricing based on geographic mix, if that was your question. It's more prices across many, many markets improving.
componenttext: And Kathryn, I think those are the most important points. I just -- we haven't had much tailwind to pricing based on geographic mix, if that was your question. It's more prices across many, many markets improving.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that was -- I guess, the point I was going to follow up on, so given you haven't seen a tailwind from geographic mix and you're also flowing through cost from acquired assets, you should see, theoretically, all things equal, improving incremental marg
componenttext: And that was -- I guess, the point I was going to follow up on, so given you haven't seen a tailwind from geographic mix and you're also flowing through cost from acquired assets, you should see, theoretically, all things equal, improving incremental margin as the year progresses.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: All things being equal.
componenttext: All things being equal.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ted Grace from Susquehanna.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ted Grace from Susquehanna.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to follow up on Trey's question. First, on the demand side. Mother nature willing, we've got 3 to 4 months left in the construction season. I'm just -- to the degree you're comfortable framing out how you're thinking about the out year, it wo
componenttext: I was hoping to follow up on Trey's question. First, on the demand side. Mother nature willing, we've got 3 to 4 months left in the construction season. I'm just -- to the degree you're comfortable framing out how you're thinking about the out year, it would be great to get a sense for what the leading edge indicators are that you're looking at. Quoting activity seems this early, looking out in the '16, kind of maybe quarterly business review highlights, anything you can kind of point to on that front that would be helpful handholding?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ted, this is John. Why don't I give a couple of numbers just to lay out a couple of benchmarks maybe, and Tom will add some additional market color in terms of what we're seeing from customers. All in all, we estimate that we've had about 4 million tons o
componenttext: Ted, this is John. Why don't I give a couple of numbers just to lay out a couple of benchmarks maybe, and Tom will add some additional market color in terms of what we're seeing from customers. All in all, we estimate that we've had about 4 million tons of aggregates shipments, to start there, deferred out of the first half. You can tell that we expect to catch up, maybe about 1 million of those in the balance of the year, just by the change in our sort of indicative guidance. A lot of that will, as you said, depend on mother nature and how long the remainder of the construction season is. And it really depends a good bit on how well many of our customers -- and Tom can comment more, how much capacity they can add, how much work they can just get done. But to give you a rough sense, of the 4 million we've seen deferred on the first half, roughly we'd expect to catch up about 1 million of that in the second half. That is less a function of any demand concern and it's more assumption of the time and capacity of our customers to get the work completed.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think well said. Ted, as you said, we probably have 4 months of solid season left. It will come down to constraints from contractors, could they get in, could they get the job, how many ready-mix trucks can they get, how fast can they get and cruis
componenttext: Yes. I think well said. Ted, as you said, we probably have 4 months of solid season left. It will come down to constraints from contractors, could they get in, could they get the job, how many ready-mix trucks can they get, how fast can they get and cruise laying asphalt? But overall, remember, this is work that we see. If we don't get it in the third quarter, fourth quarter of this year, it will follow in the first and second quarter of next year. So it won't go away, it's just postponed. And it's very normal when we have this kind of weather to see it pushed back. And when the sun comes out, we are shipping hard.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So maybe asked a little bit differently, if we were to think about kind of the comments on kind of a gradual recovery, normal recovery, would it be fair to think at least with the way you're thinking internally is growth rates of end markets in '16
componenttext: Okay. So maybe asked a little bit differently, if we were to think about kind of the comments on kind of a gradual recovery, normal recovery, would it be fair to think at least with the way you're thinking internally is growth rates of end markets in '16 could approximate '15? Or anything you might share on that end?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ted, we haven't given any guidance, obviously, we will do that at the right time. But there's nothing that -- overall, across what is a fairly, I mean call it, diversified geographic portfolio for us, we don't see anything at this point that would indicat
componenttext: Ted, we haven't given any guidance, obviously, we will do that at the right time. But there's nothing that -- overall, across what is a fairly, I mean call it, diversified geographic portfolio for us, we don't see anything at this point that would indicate a slowing momentum heading into next year. And there are always issues -- there are always state-specific issues, right, but across the portfolio in total, although we're not giving guidance, we don't see any decline in momentum.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. The second point of clarification, could you give us a bridge on EBITDA kind of 2Q '14 to 2Q '15, just -- I know that pricing is going to be a tailwind, volumes are tailwind, energy is a tailwind, acquisitions are tailwind. Can you j
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. The second point of clarification, could you give us a bridge on EBITDA kind of 2Q '14 to 2Q '15, just -- I know that pricing is going to be a tailwind, volumes are tailwind, energy is a tailwind, acquisitions are tailwind. Can you just maybe help bridge this so we can understand the headwinds more granularly? I know R&M, you said labor was up, SG&A. Just a bridge there would be great, and I'll get back in queue.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Really, I think the only headwind that we saw was probably at -- was cost in the quarter, it was slightly higher, labor cost, and I mentioned, R&M were up, the labor piece, weather causes inefficiencies and the stone operation, actually, in ready-mix and
componenttext: Really, I think the only headwind that we saw was probably at -- was cost in the quarter, it was slightly higher, labor cost, and I mentioned, R&M were up, the labor piece, weather causes inefficiencies and the stone operation, actually, in ready-mix and asphalt also. So weather affected labor also, affected the rest of our operating efficiencies and tons per gallon of fuel and electrical power. We're also beginning to run our plants with increased demand. We're starting to run our plants a little harder and longer. When you start to do this, you start to find a few weak spots in the fixed equipment. We also took the opportunity in the second quarter when we were down to do repairs, so R&M costs was up. But if you look at it from a longer-term view, our year-to-date cost is down about $0.10. On a same-store basis, it's down $0.16. Trailing 12 months, it's down $0.22. But the disciplines in operating efficiencies and operating cost is something that everybody focuses on every day. It's something you just got to stay on top of or it will get away. So I think our people are very focused on the things they control and the efficiencies in those operations. So the tailwind, I guess, I saw -- or excuse me, headwind that I saw in the quarter was really one of cost, and it was a mix of R&M and weather-related inefficiencies.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Ted, if it helps, at the gross profit line, we basically, as Tom has described, we basically got awash between some diesel benefits we had and other cost increases. So on a per unit basis, that was the cost structure base that we awash at the gross pr
componenttext: And Ted, if it helps, at the gross profit line, we basically, as Tom has described, we basically got awash between some diesel benefits we had and other cost increases. So on a per unit basis, that was the cost structure base that we awash at the gross profit line. So really, the biggest bridge, of course, gets back to volume. And again, if we had 4 million tons deferred out of the first half of aggregates, we'd estimate that's about a $35 million impact or so, plus or minus, at the EBITDA line. But the biggest factor in the quarter, unit cost were ultimately awash, managed well. Volume, of course, is a headwind, if that's helpful.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Armstrong from Vertical Research Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Armstrong from Vertical Research Partners.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the -- a follow-up on the asphalt segment. How much of the incremental operating margin was impacted due to oil prices and do you -- if oil was a significant part of that, do you believe that you'll have to pass along some of that
componenttext: My first question is on the -- a follow-up on the asphalt segment. How much of the incremental operating margin was impacted due to oil prices and do you -- if oil was a significant part of that, do you believe that you'll have to pass along some of that as the year progresses? Or will you be able to maintain those margin levels for the remainder of the year?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: There were definitely tailwinds with oil. But I think you have to look at it -- to try to separate that out when you're running over 50 asphalt plants across the whole Southwest is really difficult to do. It's really a matter of managing the uses of oil w
componenttext: There were definitely tailwinds with oil. But I think you have to look at it -- to try to separate that out when you're running over 50 asphalt plants across the whole Southwest is really difficult to do. It's really a matter of managing the uses of oil with recycled asphalt products, recycled shingles, each mix design maximizing it out and then maximizing operating efficiencies and the cost just to run the operations, along with sales and service and value and price. So I think that to try to separate that out is pretty tough to do. As far as getting that back, getting back any savings on oil, we don't see that -- those headwinds at this point. You don't know that for sure. But I think that right now, we're pretty confident in our ability to manage the combination of customer service material margin operating cost and continue what we're doing today.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the aggregates segment. As we go into the back half of the year, have the regions in which you're seeing pricing momentum changed from what you saw in the first half of the year? And can you detail that a little bit more for us?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the aggregates segment. As we go into the back half of the year, have the regions in which you're seeing pricing momentum changed from what you saw in the first half of the year? And can you detail that a little bit more for us?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that anything's changed as far as the momentum we see on the pricing. Obviously, the more mature markets in recovery -- the markets that are more mature in recovery, the cost price lags volume or seen the bigger jump in pricing. But overall,
componenttext: I don't know that anything's changed as far as the momentum we see on the pricing. Obviously, the more mature markets in recovery -- the markets that are more mature in recovery, the cost price lags volume or seen the bigger jump in pricing. But overall, I don't -- I think the trend is pretty steady. I think we'll continue -- not only is it steady, but it will continue to improve as we go forward. And as we said earlier, we'll be back-half-loaded with the price improvement.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the rates vary substantially across markets, but I think, to come back to what Tom said, I think all of our states saw pricing increase on a same-store basis at some level. So a trend, if we went back a few quarters, would be that it's broadening. The
componenttext: And the rates vary substantially across markets, but I think, to come back to what Tom said, I think all of our states saw pricing increase on a same-store basis at some level. So a trend, if we went back a few quarters, would be that it's broadening. The rate vary substantially across states, but the trend would be that it's been broadening.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Timna Tanners from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Timna Tanners from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's actually PT Luther, in for Timna today. You made some pretty universally positive comments in terms of demand trends. I just wanted to check and see if you are seeing much leakage just from the weaker energy market in any of your -- among any of your
componenttext: It's actually PT Luther, in for Timna today. You made some pretty universally positive comments in terms of demand trends. I just wanted to check and see if you are seeing much leakage just from the weaker energy market in any of your -- among any of your customers, maybe in LNG projects, things like that.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you look at the energy projects along the coast, the LNG projects, the refinery projects, we're actually seeing that to continue to pick up. My guess is we'll ship over 2 million tons to that segment on the coast. Remember, the reason why we're so adva
componenttext: If you look at the energy projects along the coast, the LNG projects, the refinery projects, we're actually seeing that to continue to pick up. My guess is we'll ship over 2 million tons to that segment on the coast. Remember, the reason why we're so advantaged with our bluewater delivery to those projects require big volumes by water in a short amount of time. So if you put that over 2 million to 2.5 million this year, I will tell you that next year, from what we know right now, we will -- and this is what we had probably under contract, we'd be just south of 2 million, there's probably on the drawing board another 8 million tons in projects that are out there that haven't bid, they're still in the permitting or planning process. So no slowdown in the energy projects along the coast.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then in terms of the pricing momentum you're talking about in the second half, was that primarily from price hikes that you've already implemented and announced in the first half? Or does some of that assumes some additional price hikes in the
componenttext: Great. And then in terms of the pricing momentum you're talking about in the second half, was that primarily from price hikes that you've already implemented and announced in the first half? Or does some of that assumes some additional price hikes in the second half as well?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: As we always say, our pricing is across dozens of markets. So each one's individual, then you've got -- within those markets, you have fixed plants where you've got price increases that come at all different times of the year. And then you got quoted work
componenttext: As we always say, our pricing is across dozens of markets. So each one's individual, then you've got -- within those markets, you have fixed plants where you've got price increases that come at all different times of the year. And then you got quoted work which you are pressing price with each quote each week. So it is a combination of what we've secured, pricing that will quote higher in the second half and then announced price increases in the second half. And then you also working off all work. So you got to put all that into the mix. And again, you've got to aggregate all those pricing movements across all those markets.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Garik Shmois from Longbow Research.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on diesel. You had a nice benefit here in the second quarter. I think coming into the beginning of the year, we thought there could be potential upside because of diesel savings. Just wondering how you're thinking about diesel costs in t
componenttext: First question is on diesel. You had a nice benefit here in the second quarter. I think coming into the beginning of the year, we thought there could be potential upside because of diesel savings. Just wondering how you're thinking about diesel costs in the back half of the year as it relates to your overall EBITDA guidance?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, if you look at our guidance, this goes into individual operations. And so there is diesel savings built in from the ground-up perspective in the second half of the year. There's also -- built to that is labor cost, and repair and maintenance cost
componenttext: I think, if you look at our guidance, this goes into individual operations. And so there is diesel savings built in from the ground-up perspective in the second half of the year. There's also -- built to that is labor cost, and repair and maintenance costs and operating supplies and parts. So I think when you put that all together, if you look at our guidance, we do have diesel built into it.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess it's fair to assume that some of the other cost you just mentioned will partially offset.
componenttext: I guess it's fair to assume that some of the other cost you just mentioned will partially offset.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's the right way to think about it, Garik. I don't know that we're the world's best at predicting future diesel prices and those kinds of things, but we will begin to comp over, if you will, lower cost as we get into the third and fourth quart
componenttext: I think that's the right way to think about it, Garik. I don't know that we're the world's best at predicting future diesel prices and those kinds of things, but we will begin to comp over, if you will, lower cost as we get into the third and fourth quarter. So I think you summed it up well which is we would expect to continue to manage to improving margins in the second half in total. And underneath that's a mix of several factors, probably a little help from diesel costs, probably a little bit higher repair and maintenance cost than we've seen in the past.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just shifting to capital allocation, you mentioned, I think it was $30 million or so to update your Panamax fleet. Just wondering if this is in relation to any sort of capacity addition that you're undergoing in the Cancun facility and if we should antici
componenttext: Just shifting to capital allocation, you mentioned, I think it was $30 million or so to update your Panamax fleet. Just wondering if this is in relation to any sort of capacity addition that you're undergoing in the Cancun facility and if we should anticipate increased volumes coming out for your long-haul operations.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: These are specific replacements for the ships that we started that operations with. So those ships are some 30 years old. It's time for them to retire for all kinds of reasons. Now what we will get in the new ships is with the technology, we'll have a lit
componenttext: These are specific replacements for the ships that we started that operations with. So those ships are some 30 years old. It's time for them to retire for all kinds of reasons. Now what we will get in the new ships is with the technology, we'll have a little more payload and we'll have much better fuel efficiencies and probably a little better speed out of those ships. So we'll get better efficiencies. But the bottom line of that is those ships are replacements.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I'll ask the highway bill question. You sounded pretty optimistic in your prepared remarks around the new highway bill. Just wondering, it's early, but if you could provide some thoughts on -- if we do get a multiyear bill towards the end
componenttext: Okay. And then, I'll ask the highway bill question. You sounded pretty optimistic in your prepared remarks around the new highway bill. Just wondering, it's early, but if you could provide some thoughts on -- if we do get a multiyear bill towards the end of the year, potentially what kind of volume opportunity would that imply for aggregates demand moving forward?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we put a number to that because there's got so many unknowns in that highway bill and what does it mean, we have not at this point. The one thing I will say is that a long-term bill, even at the funding we have today is a good thing for
componenttext: I don't know that we put a number to that because there's got so many unknowns in that highway bill and what does it mean, we have not at this point. The one thing I will say is that a long-term bill, even at the funding we have today is a good thing for us because it gives security to those states so they -- and we've got a number of states that are pushing back big jobs because they don't have security they're going to get paid by federal government. So at worst case, if we get flat funding with a long-term bill, we look at it as a very good thing. At the same time, we've got a number of states, which have already substantially increased their funding, and we have a number of very key states to us, including California, which are looking at the way you recognize that they have to increase their funding and are taking steps towards that. So overall, with the steps that the Senate's taking and the Congress -- the House is taking, we're pleased with it, we've got high hopes for it, we think we've got a lot of momentum. And on top of that, you've got the momentum of improving state funding or the recognition that state funding has to increase.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jerry Revich from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to continue the discussion on the regulatory side, California is in session or the legislation is in session about potentially increasing state highway funding. How optimistic are you that something goes through? And what's your sense on where that p
componenttext: Just to continue the discussion on the regulatory side, California is in session or the legislation is in session about potentially increasing state highway funding. How optimistic are you that something goes through? And what's your sense on where that process stands now?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you a little background -- yes, let me give you a little background on California. Their highway bill right now is at about $11 billion annually. If things stays status quo, they'd cut that to 5% to about $10.5 billion. They recognize that the
componenttext: Let me give you a little background -- yes, let me give you a little background on California. Their highway bill right now is at about $11 billion annually. If things stays status quo, they'd cut that to 5% to about $10.5 billion. They recognize that they have to take steps to not only keep that whole but to improve it. Their Senate Bill 16, which is out there right now, which would improve, would increase it by another $3 billion, it's too early to give you a guess on that at this point or prediction. I think the good thing is that they recognize that they have a shortfall, they're going to have to address it and they're taking steps for it. So -- and [indiscernible] in these roads, California sure does. So they do recognize it, and the leadership there is taking steps to improve it.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And sorry, what's your sense on timing, how do you expect it to play out?
componenttext: And sorry, what's your sense on timing, how do you expect it to play out?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then in the press release you highlighted stripping costs and just naturally mine plans evolve as companies get price increases, can you just counsel us on how to think about stripping cost over the next couple of years? How much are you changing mine
componenttext: And then in the press release you highlighted stripping costs and just naturally mine plans evolve as companies get price increases, can you just counsel us on how to think about stripping cost over the next couple of years? How much are you changing mine plans as pricing is picking up here?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know that we're changing mine plans with pricing, that wouldn't drive a mine plan, it's really based on the long-term operations of a quarry. Obviously, as volume goes up, you just have to strip more just because you have -- you're producing more
componenttext: I don't know that we're changing mine plans with pricing, that wouldn't drive a mine plan, it's really based on the long-term operations of a quarry. Obviously, as volume goes up, you just have to strip more just because you have -- you're producing more tons. I think other times is we are opportunistic when we strip. So maybe when we're not running an operation for whatever reason, we take accrued equipment and go strip because it's just good sense and good use of cost. But overall, I don't see -- price didn't have an impact, volume obviously does because you just have to strip more with more volume. And in each individual mine, it's based on what that operation has to do for the long term. I mean we're running these operations for decades, not a few years, so -- and stripping is a big part of the long-term planning.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015

componenttext: I think -- let me add a little bit to that. I think it's more about momentum and you're seeing -- we told you that price was going to follow volume, and that as volume continue to grow, pricing would grow behind it. And that was very apparent in the second quarter. I think as we continue to see volume grow, you can continue to see pricing momentum grow, not just a percentage but overall pricing will continue to accelerate.

componenttext: Worth a shot. And then -- but just in general, I mean it feels like volume -- it feels you've been a little conservative with the volume expectations in the back half. I mean, I guess you're assuming the 3 million tons are either lost because of the weather or maybe pushed to '16?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Aug 04, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- for sure, they're not lost. Those jobs are not going away. Our customer's having backlog, they're doing the work. It's really a matter of if you look at hundreds of jobs and even the fixed plant with hundreds of jobs, can they get on that
componenttext: Yes, I think -- for sure, they're not lost. Those jobs are not going away. Our customer's having backlog, they're doing the work. It's really a matter of if you look at hundreds of jobs and even the fixed plant with hundreds of jobs, can they get on that job? Can they get it all done in the compressed amount of time they have to do it in the construction season 2015? So if they don't get it done, it will push back into first quarter, second quarter of '16. Now if you look at asphalt and, for example, in asphalt, our ready-mix plant is do they have the plant capacity and the truck capacity to catch up from where they are? Again, it's not lost. If it doesn't happen in '15, it will happen in '16. And as I said earlier, this is really normal for when we have severe weather like this, we'll do the work. it's just a matter of timing.
