headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Vulcan Materials Company Third Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Tabitha, and I'll be a conference call coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] And now, I'd like to turn the call over to your host, Mr. Mark Warren, Director of Investor R
componenttext: Welcome to the Vulcan Materials Company Third Quarter Earnings Call. My name is Tabitha, and I'll be a conference call coordinator today. [Operator Instructions] And now, I'd like to turn the call over to your host, Mr. Mark Warren, Director of Investor Relations for Vulcan Materials. Mr. Warren, you may begin.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tabitha. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for your interest in Vulcan Materials. Joining me today for this call are Tom Hill, President and CEO; and John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. Please not
componenttext:
Thank you, Tabitha. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for your interest in Vulcan Materials. Joining me today for this call are Tom Hill, President and CEO; and John McPherson, Executive Vice President, Chief Financial and Strategy Officer. Please note a slide presentation will accompany the prepared remarks by management and is available via the webcast. A copy of this presentation, as well as a replay of the conference call will be available following the conclusion of this call at the company's website. 
Before we begin with actual results and projections, I refer you to Slide 2 of our presentation regarding forward-looking statements, which are subject to risks and uncertainties. Descriptions of these are detailed in our most recent report on Form 10-K. In addition, during this call, management will refer to certain non-GAAP financial measurements. You will find a reconciliation of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures and other related information in our earnings release and at the end of this presentation. Now, I'd like to turn the call over to Vulcan's Chief Executive Officer, Tom Hill. Tom?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mark, and thank all of you for joining us today for our third quarter earnings call. At Vulcan, we posted another strong quarter and we remain on track to have a very good year. Our solid performance, continued revenue growth and margin expansi
componenttext:
Thank you, Mark, and thank all of you for joining us today for our third quarter earnings call. At Vulcan, we posted another strong quarter and we remain on track to have a very good year. Our solid performance, continued revenue growth and margin expansion are a direct result of the great efforts of our people. Today, you're going to hear about steady recovery, solid price improvement and about our sharp focus on the things we can control. Now, we won't be giving guidance for 2016 in today's call but as we began our planning cycle for next year, our fundamental trajectory remains intact. We continue to experience a gradual steady recovery in demand and shipments. Although the details of course vary from market to market, we also continue to see positive pricing climate with appropriate increases either announced or plan for next year. We remain well positioned to convert incremental revenues into incremental gross profit at an impressive clip. We are excited about the opportunities ahead. Our people know that they must remain highly focused on margin improvement and continue to drive ongoing improvements in our business. We're focused on capitalizing on our momentum. Our people are engaged and entrepreneurial and they are sharing best practices across the organization. They know that they are a power to serve our customers and keep making our company more profitable and better in every way. We, also, all of us remain highly focused on safe operations, protecting the health and safety of our employees at all times. 
Now to company specifics. The recovery in construction activity continue across most of our markets. As we will show you, the metrics are certainly, trending in the right direction. While demand is recovering gradually to more normal levels, we have enjoyed sustained margin expansion and we continue to grow our profitability in a disciplined manner. As construction activity and materials demand continue to pick up, we are also seeing improving confidence in pricing. Now, we've had some cost increases during the last 2 quarters. Even though some of this is expected given volume growth, we are very focused on continually improving our operating performance. These efforts begin to pay off in September when we saw marked improvement in our costs. We are going to stay very focused on this. Our employees are doing a really good job, turning incremental revenues into incremental profits. And let me add, we see these trends continuing. We are heading into 2016 with the win in our back. That said, we are totally focused on finishing this year strong. 
Now let's talk about the third quarter. Demand continue to recover gradually in the quarter. Our results demonstrated the earnings leverage in our business model. With improving market conditions and our focus on profit improvements, both pricing and margins continue to expand. As you can see on Slide 4, a 19% increase in total revenues converted to a 39% increase in gross profit. This also drove a 47% increase in adjusted EBIT and a 31% increase in adjusted EBITDA. Our diluted earnings per share from continuing operations increased 82%. Adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations were $0.95 per diluted share, an increase of $0.41 from the prior year. Gross profit margins increased by 490 basis points and were supported by pricing momentum. We enjoyed strong earnings growth in aggregates, as well as in our asphalt and concrete segments. We continue to manage and leverage SAG. SAG cost did increase in absolute terms. Here, onetime items offset lower headcount related costs. What's important is as a percent of sales, SAG is trending towards 8% for the year, down about 1% from the prior year. All in all, I'm very pleased with our people's performance. You know whether measured by margin percentage or per unit profit, our profitably continue to improve very significantly. 
Now let's take a look at our shipments across the U.S. The map on Slide 5 shows a breakdown of our growth in shipments of aggregates on a same-store basis across the country. In the quarter, we saw solid demand growth even though many customers face bottlenecks impeding shipments. It's important to recognize what a good job our local teams are doing working with our customers to meet rising demand effectively and efficiently. Momentum continue with solid growth in key states. Shipments in Arizona, California, Florida, Georgia, South Carolina, Texas and Louisiana, each grew by 10% or more. In contrast, majority of our markets which were up, Illinois was down about 10%. This was due to significant large project work completed in 2014. Now at the same time, California saw healthy growth in the third quarter as major projects kicked off after being delayed in the first half of the year. 
I'd like to turn your attention to Slide 6 which shows our year-over-year growth in shipments. As you can see, this is a very similar pattern to the last slide with solid year-to-date growth in aggregate shipments of 10% in total or 7% on a same-store basis. Both our East and West Coast markets continue to enjoy healthy growth as did Texas. Shipments in the Gulf Coast markets were also strong with the exception of the Central Gulf Coast region. 
Turn to Slide 7. You can see that our pricing continues to strengthen and for the quarter, it improved in line with our expectations of 8% over the prior year's quarter. In a number of markets, we saw year-over-year freight adjusted price improvements in excess of 10%. This increases were fairly broad-based and occurred across all product types. And in more than half of our markets, we've had price increases ranging from $0.60 to $1.20 per ton. For the quarter, we didn't see this level of price increases in Virginia, South Carolina and Arizona because we had much larger shipments of base material refines on new construction and large projects. As discussed before, volume and basin finds can attract from price but improves overall profitability. Let me emphasize the fact that pricing momentum will continue for us. There are 3 primary reasons that the pricing climate should remain positive: 1, customer confidence continues to improve; 2, increasing demand builds backlog; and third, construction related businesses are increasingly focused on earning adequate returns. Effective pricing performance remains a key focus for our management teams across our footprint. We are focused on delivering value to customers while earning a good return on the significant investments that we make on their behalf. This ties directly to providing excellent service to our customers, the right product, the right quality, the right time and being paid the right price for superior service and value. 
Now we've talked a lot on past calls about the 3 profit drivers that are expanding our margins and profits. That's because it's important. As a reminder, the 3 profit drivers are sales and production mix, price and operating efficiencies. We call these the 3 circles. As you can see on Slide 8, our third quarter and trailing 12 month gross profit per ton increased 23% and 25%, respectively. So in the quarter, on a same-store basis, price was up $0.86 per ton and gross profit margin was up $0.90 per ton. Our sales and operations people are doing a superior job turning demand growth into higher profitability. Our local teams continue to do an outstanding job managing the combination of price, operating efficiencies, volume and product mix. This is something we will stay focused on every day. With respect to the 3 circles, we've talked about the positive pricing environment and we've talked about new construction improving the impact of product mix on profitability. Regarding the third circle, operating efficiencies and leverage. We continue to emphasize production planning and operating efficiencies across the business. Despite improvements in unit profitability and same-store cost, we are seeing some areas of rising cost. As I mentioned, I'm not satisfied with this and neither are our people. Still, we're seeing some cost rise. About 2/3 of these increases resulted from geographic mix and fringe benefits, also outside our control. In addition, during the last 2 quarters, we have begun to see a trend of rising repair maintenance and labor cost in some areas. Even though this isn't surprising, we are not going to accept that. Growing volumes are requiring us to run operations longer, resulting in more repairs and higher than budgeted spending across our supplies. And labor cost in some areas were up in the first 8 months of the year. We saw cost go up, we focused on them and we realized improvements in September. We will continue manage these costs very carefully. 
Let's turn to Slide 9. Our employees can be very proud of this chart. It clearly shows that are people are highly focused on continuous improvement and quality of earnings. We're excited by the ongoing very positive trend in unit margin expansion. We have now seen 9 consecutive quarters of expanding unit margin and will continue to post improvements. Since our volumes begin to grow in the second half of 2013, our gross profit per ton has increased sharply. We are now seeing the additional benefits of strong and ongoing improvement in pricing. Our unit profitability is higher than when these operations were producing twice the volume. Again, I would expect this trend to continue into 2016. 
Slide 10 shows on our incremental margin performance in the aggregate segment. This underpins the margin improvement you saw on the previous slide. Our incremental gross profit margin for the third quarter was 72%, excluding the impact of acquisitions completed during 2014. Aggregate's gross profit grew by $60 million on incremental freight adjusted revenues of $83 million. Including the impact of acquisitions, the incremental margin was 65% with a gross margin on those revenues impacted mainly by higher cost at acquired operations as we bring them up to our standards, and by higher cost for repair maintenance. Now since quarterly figures can be distorted by seasonality or onetime cost, we also present the same metric on a trailing 12 month basis. For this time period, incremental gross profit margin was 73%. Aggregates' growth profit increased approximately $177 million or incremental revenues of $242 million, adjusted for the same acquisitions. On a trailing 12 month basis, the flow through rate was consistently exceeded the company's stated goal of 60% since volumes begin to recover in the second half of 2013. Given our strategic focus on the aggregates business, our ability to take that revenue to the bottom line is a big advantage for Vulcan as volumes continued to recover. With that, I'll turn the call over to John for additional comments on our earnings performance and outlook for the remainder of the year. John?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. I'll begin with Slide 11 and we did last quarter use it to recap any of the trends Tom just reviewed. On this slide, we highlight the improved [Audio Gap]Sorry, thanks, Tom. I'll begin with Slide 11 and as we last quarter, use it to recap
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. I'll begin with Slide 11 and we did last quarter use it to recap any of the trends Tom just reviewed. On this slide, we highlight the improved 
[Audio Gap]
Sorry, thanks, Tom. I'll begin with Slide 11 and as we last quarter, use it to recap many of the trend Tom just reviewed. On this slide, we highlight the improve profitability of our aggregates segment, both in total gross profit dollars and on a per ton basis since the recovery in volumes began in the second half of 2013. On the left-hand side of the chart, you see that for the trailing 12 months just ended, we shipped 175 million tons, 35 million tons more than for the trailing 12 months ending in the second quarter of 2013 just before the recovery began. Now looking to the right-hand side of the chart, you see that aggregates segment gross profit for the 12 months just ended was $682 million or $324 million ahead of the 12 months before the recovery began. So on $35 million of incremental aggregates tons shipped so far in the recovery, we've delivered $324 million in incremental segment gross profit. Gross profit per ton has increased $1.35 or 53%. And a 25% increase in shipments has been converted into a 90% increase in segment gross profit. These facts we believe illustrate the impact of the continuous compounding performance improvements you heard Tom reference and that in many ways characterized our current aggregates centric strategy and execution focus. 
Now turning to Slide 12 which shows the solid performance of our asphalt and concrete businesses for the third quarter. Segment gross profit and unit profitability in each of these segments increased significantly versus the prior year and year-to-date, the gross profit from these businesses has exceeded plan. Asphalt gross profit for the quarter was $30 million, a year-over-year improvement of $15 million, driven by improving same-store volumes, strong cost disciplines and margin management, as well as the impact of acquired operations. As a reminder, our acquisition this fall activities has added 19 asphalt plants to our store portfolio since the second half of last year. On a same-store basis, asphalt volumes grew 20%, in part due to work deferred from the first half of the year and asphalt gross profit grew $11 million. Vulcan is some of the 5 largest producers of asphalt in the country and these operations complement our aggregates operations very well. Third quarter concrete gross profit was approximately $10 million compared to $5 million in the prior quarter and the prior year. Margins in this business segment have benefited from divestitures and other actions to focus our portfolio. The operations we have divested lost $2 million at the gross profit line in the prior year quarter. On a same-store basis, concrete volumes were flat versus the prior year and gross profit improved by $3 million. 
I'll now wrap up with Slide 13 and a recap of our full year 2015 outlook before handing the call back to Tom for some closing remarks. In short, our outlook for the full year remains largely consistent with that, presented in our second quarter call, and we are reaffirming our expectations for full-year adjusted EBITDA in the range of $775 million to $825 million. As usual, we note that weather patterns can impact results of the fourth quarter significantly, particularly if they shorten the total construction season. But, and as you've seen earlier in this call, the business is performing well and it is performing as expected. Now taking through a few of the individual drivers. We currently expect full-year volumes of approximately 177 million tons, up 9% year-on-year in total and 7% on a same-store basis. As noted earlier, we see the gradual recovery in demand continuing across most of our markets. However, capacity constraints at various points in the construction chain. For example, the availability of steel construction labor in certain markets have made it difficult for many of our customers to catch up fully on work deferred due to rain in the first half of the year. On the continued uncertainty regarding highway legislation has begun to impact timing of certain road projects on the margin. With respect to pricing, we expect the currently positive environment to persist and we currently expect to finish 2015 with a year-on-year increase in average freight adjusted selling prices of approximately 7%. As we've indicated, pressing momentum in the second half of the year has been stronger than in the first half of the year. Our asphalt and concrete segments have performed ahead of plan, both on a same-store basis and as a result of moves we made to strengthen our portfolio. These segments should generate full-year gross profit of approximately $95 million but again, please note that fourth quarter weather patterns can significantly impact actual results. SAG remains roughly in line with plan and declining as a percent of sales. Importantly, direct salary and wage cost for SAG headcount have remained flat this year and we do not expect the rise of pension and other postretirement benefit cost that we've had this year to reoccur next year. Core capital spending excluding dollars committed to the purchase of new ships to service our Yucatn quarry remains in line with plan. As noted in our earnings release, we may elect to pull some spending forward from 2016 in order to capitalize on certain procurement opportunities. As has been our practice, we plan to issue guidance for our 2016 year during our February earnings call. And certainly, a number of things can change between now and then, including federal highway legislation which Tom will touch on in a moment. But as we sit here in early November, we see volume and pricing trends similar to those we've seen year-to-date continuing to the fourth quarter and in the next year. And we of course remain intently focused on converting that top line revenue growth into cash flow and earnings growth to the very best of our ability. As Tom said at the beginning of the call, our basic trajectory remains intact. Tom, back to you.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our employees are working hard to ensure our strong performance, continue revenue growth and margin expansion. I can't say enough good things about our people. They never quit, always try to do things better. I have enormous pride in what th
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our employees are working hard to ensure our strong performance, continue revenue growth and margin expansion. I can't say enough good things about our people. They never quit, always try to do things better. I have enormous pride in what they do and I see this every day. Our priority is continuous improvement. We're going to stay very focused on the things that we can control, on keeping our people safe, on customer service, on controlling cost and on price. We'll get fair value for the major investments we make in this business. I can tell you it's all about creating value for our customers and our companies. 
Now before I conclude, I'd like to say a few things about the Highway Bill. I reported last call about the significant progress in Washington towards the new bill. The Senate, with great leadership did its job when it passed the new six-year bill to drive act on July 30. The House transportation and infrastructure committee marked up its version of the Highway Bill 2 weeks ago. Congressional leaders believe it may be possible to conference the 2 bills and pass the final Highway Bill before the end of November. We are encouraged by the progress that is occurring in Congress to address America's infrastructure challenges. We have been very engaged in efforts to encourage Congress to step up to this challenge, a new multiyear Highway bill will be a step in the right direction and our nation's leaders will need to take additional steps in the years to come. This is important for our country, our industry and for Vulcan. 
In closing, I truly appreciate your interest in Vulcan Materials Company. Looking forward, to the rest of 2015 and into 2016, I want you to know that we are very energized and engaged. We are focused on the fundamentals, on finding new ways to grow our company and its profitability every day. Now, if the operator will give the required instructions, we will be happy to respond to your questions.

componenttext: Tom, I hate to lead off on a question on '16 given your opening comments, so I won't ask specifically for guidance but just as it relates to maybe the slope of that trajectory heading into next year because it seems like depending on whether 4Q probably comes in a little bit below plan given some of the commentary. Obviously, 1 of large peers gives some guidance that people are interpreting as off trend growth, so I'm just wondering do you have any kind of handholding whether it's market related expectations on how people should think about that slope. I know John just said basic trajectory intact but anyway you could kind of frame out, anything would be helpful. We have a good start there.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me start with demand. We're seeing demand growth in all their major markets. The vast majority of them and in the market segments. More than have over markets in the third quarter saw double-digit growth, little bit of lagging as we talk about what Mi
componenttext: Let me start with demand. We're seeing demand growth in all their major markets. The vast majority of them and in the market segments. More than have over markets in the third quarter saw double-digit growth, little bit of lagging as we talk about what Mississippi instead of the country but overall, we continue to see healthy demand growth whether that's across geographies or market segments. So we don't see anything that would give us pause for slowdown whether the fourth quarter or afterwards. Now if you look at the same thing on price, we continue to see very healthy climate for price increases. Now that's built by customer confidence and by rising demand.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, the super helpful. And maybe if I could just quickly tuck one in on cost. I know you talked about being somewhat above expectations last couple of quarters. You mentioned some of the factors in the third quarter including more recently labor and  R&
componenttext: Okay, the super helpful. And maybe if I could just quickly tuck one in on cost. I know you talked about being somewhat above expectations last couple of quarters. You mentioned some of the factors in the third quarter including more recently labor and  R&M taking up, taking some proactive action to address that. Just when we think about the normal framework of incremental you've talked about, is there any tweaking we should think about and kind of the next 1 or 2 years that could affect that to anything meaningful degree or is that still going to be useful framework as we think about just normalize flow-through rates?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ted, I don't see anything that would change the fundamentals of our earnings leverage or trajectory. Is just not there and alleges the third quarter. Our cost of the third quarter year-over-year 1 same-store basis were down about a nickel. Building that w
componenttext: Ted, I don't see anything that would change the fundamentals of our earnings leverage or trajectory. Is just not there and alleges the third quarter. Our cost of the third quarter year-over-year 1 same-store basis were down about a nickel. Building that was diesel, was down about $0.23. The increase occurred in fringes and geographic mix. That was about 2/3 of it, which geographic mix is usually remote distribution network or higher cost markets. That will always fix the sales without to come back around. The fringes are one time or won't last. The other piece of that was R&M which is natural for this time of the cycle. And then, in some areas, we've had labor cost that were up in the second quarter and the third quarter. We recognize those. I think our folks did a good job of addressing those and we saw marked improvement in cost overall in September. So it's a -- what's important here is that we focus on things that we can control. It's imperative that we always try to improve that and as that compounding effort of every day and every quarry of making it better and compounding those earnings.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, Ted if you just check for those 3 big drivers of cost, none of them are really structural in our view. 1 is geographic mix shipping from higher cost locations or markets and frankly, that comes typically with higher price and higher-margin markets as
componenttext: So, Ted if you just check for those 3 big drivers of cost, none of them are really structural in our view. 1 is geographic mix shipping from higher cost locations or markets and frankly, that comes typically with higher price and higher-margin markets as well. So that as Tom said, will correct that itself and that's not a bad thing. On fringes, on the subway benefit related cost, most of that including the pension accounting issues, we don't see repeating next year and will correct for. And then I think Tom gave you a clear explanation for how we've addressed to some degree already some of the temporary headwinds we've seen and repair maintenance cost and labor cost.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kathryn Thompson with Thompson Research Group.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that you helped to answer to the questions I had about the higher cost which were more onetime in nature versus embedded cost on a go forward basis. Just to clean up that question that you had -- the answer that you were just giving in the previou
componenttext: I think that you helped to answer to the questions I had about the higher cost which were more onetime in nature versus embedded cost on a go forward basis. Just to clean up that question that you had -- the answer that you were just giving in the previous queue, how far along are you in terms of resolving some of those cost that at least you made progress in September but is this something realistically, it will be more of a Q1 before you really kind of fully cleaned up? Although it will be some residual particularly from a geographic mix and we see lingering into Q4.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me give you an example of labor. I think we got ahead of ourselves in a few markets in labor where we thought margins could come back faster than it did. We hired too many people and actually, had to go correct it when we saw it wasn't going to happen
componenttext: Let me give you an example of labor. I think we got ahead of ourselves in a few markets in labor where we thought margins could come back faster than it did. We hired too many people and actually, had to go correct it when we saw it wasn't going to happen. We also were running a number of places we're running 4 plants with 2 crews and we've made some structural scheduling mistakes there which we corrected. So a lot of this I think we've taken really good steps to recognize the problem. It's why we have good metrics and folks look at it really hard and they've corrected it and then John -- as far as the geographic mix, that will come and go. I don't see anything structurally that. You'll get that back, actually.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then if you could -- I know that year ago quarter, you may quite a few acquisitions. Could you once again break out how much the contribution from the quarter were in terms of revenue and earnings contribution were from acquired assets versus just cor
componenttext: And then if you could -- I know that year ago quarter, you may quite a few acquisitions. Could you once again break out how much the contribution from the quarter were in terms of revenue and earnings contribution were from acquired assets versus just core?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, the adjusted EBITDA for the acquisitions of the quarter was in the range of $13 million. I think overall, our acquisitions are going well. We're pleased with the assets and the personnel that we had at Vulcan. I'm happy with the integration job our f
componenttext: Yes, the adjusted EBITDA for the acquisitions of the quarter was in the range of $13 million. I think overall, our acquisitions are going well. We're pleased with the assets and the personnel that we had at Vulcan. I'm happy with the integration job our folks did and getting those tucked in and going. We're pleased with how it fits into our network. So overall, we're very please with the acquisitions and like what we got.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Kathryn, we can break out for you revenue and gross profit by division by segment of acquisitions off-line if you'd like. I think in total, we're probably trending toward -- I think we've said $40 million to $50 million of EBITDA at the beginning of t
componenttext: And Kathryn, we can break out for you revenue and gross profit by division by segment of acquisitions off-line if you'd like. I think in total, we're probably trending toward -- I think we've said $40 million to $50 million of EBITDA at the beginning of the year. We're quite trending toward the low end of that range full year. Still very satisfied with the performance. But as we've noted, we've had some increased investments to better manage the mine plans and improve production capacity of certain product types and some of the acquired facilities. And that explain some amount of -- that explains part of why we lowered into that range but exquisitely where we're tracking around -- around $40 million but not towards $50 million.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Perfect. And then, my final question is about aggregate pricing. You've seen some accelerating in pricing as the years progressed and really actually, from prior year of and carrying into Q3. Twofold question. Are there certain markets we're seeing greate
componenttext: Perfect. And then, my final question is about aggregate pricing. You've seen some accelerating in pricing as the years progressed and really actually, from prior year of and carrying into Q3. Twofold question. Are there certain markets we're seeing greater pricing leverage? And then, 2, we've just received anecdotal feedback from the field that specifically in the Southeast, you have had always change your pricing structurally but certainly, being more proactive in terms of getting pricing equally across all of your main product segments being base buying. Maybe if you could either confirm or flush out that feedback that you've been getting in the field.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that the pricing clearance we see right now is very positive and very predictable with the pricing following the volume. I think the good news is what we're seeing going into '15 and going into '16 is a very healthy pricing environment. We've
componenttext: Yes. I think that the pricing clearance we see right now is very positive and very predictable with the pricing following the volume. I think the good news is what we're seeing going into '15 and going into '16 is a very healthy pricing environment. We've got steady rising demand in the vast majority of markets. That's driving customer and construction industry confidence which is always a good thing for pricing but one of the things we always have the remember is pricing is a campaign. It's something you do every day. It's thousands of price decisions every week and it's also about the compounding improvements over time of not just pricing but more of expansions. So our employees are striving hard to improve the rate for our customers and I think that if you step back and look at it, the environment that we're in right now that we closed into 2016 is very healthy for pricing improvements.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Garik Shmois with Longbow Research.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Just wanted touch on demand and maybe if you could speak to any change in trends with respect to the demand segments, whether it's infrastructure, non-res or residential. I know you commented that you're seeing steady progression on volumes but has there been any, whether exchange in fitting or fretting or acceleration or deceleration [indiscernible]

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that as I said earlier, we're seeing good demand growth across all segments. Now in the non-res piece like you, we've seen the leading indicators and we've seen them dip a little bit but on the ground when it comes to shipments or bidding pro
componenttext: Yes, I think that as I said earlier, we're seeing good demand growth across all segments. Now in the non-res piece like you, we've seen the leading indicators and we've seen them dip a little bit but on the ground when it comes to shipments or bidding projects, we have not seen any dip in non-res demand. The good news is we're starting to see improvements in residential and in highway work. So overall, we're continuously steady growth, demand growth.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, if you maybe pieces of additional color since we know this is an area of focus for folks. From a geographic point of view, it's almost easier to talk up at the ends of the spectrum so in terms of recovery toward normalized demand for us, one in the
componenttext: Garik, if you maybe pieces of additional color since we know this is an area of focus for folks. From a geographic point of view, it's almost easier to talk up at the ends of the spectrum so in terms of recovery toward normalized demand for us, one in the spectrums certainly, we have some Texas markets, they're a bit further along in the recovery. In our view, still doing quite well but a bit further along. And on the other end, as Thomas mentioned before, we have our Mississippi, Alabama, Illinois, kind of our middle of the country markets that really haven't gotten much momentum yet in terms of the recovery moving along. But everything else is making pretty good progress. The facts and circumstances vary by market but everything else is making pretty good progress. The 1 issue that we do continue to see in some markets and it will inform all of our plants for 2016 when we get there is just the pace at which this growing demand and recovery demand really gets turn into aggregate shipments and again, in some markets that's a function of large project timing and how quickly do you DoTs can get their raised level of funding out the door into new projects, so we'll monitor that closely. And in other markets, that's a function of these,  if you will, bottlenecks in the construction supply chain that we referenced were availability of crews or equipment or develops land or skilled trade labor, those can really be the terminus of how quickly we grow. So net net, we continue to see across the portfolio a steady gradual repeating recovery just basically the same kind of trend we've been on for 2015.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. That's very helpful. Just wanted to dive in to start around the fourth quarter and your annual guidance, it's really wide range that you left for EBITDA or fourth quarter. Just want to be clear on that range and what could drive the upper and lower
componenttext: Great. That's very helpful. Just wanted to dive in to start around the fourth quarter and your annual guidance, it's really wide range that you left for EBITDA or fourth quarter. Just want to be clear on that range and what could drive the upper and lower and. It's really just a function of whether project timing or is there anything else that we should be paying attention to?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Garik, it's John. We're not trying to signal anything by the breadth of that range, so I wouldn't read too much into it first. I read it as unchanged from our last call, that would be the main message because as I went through most of the underlying drive
componenttext: Garik, it's John. We're not trying to signal anything by the breadth of that range, so I wouldn't read too much into it first. I read it as unchanged from our last call, that would be the main message because as I went through most of the underlying drivers that we've seen are basically still on track with our last discussion on our last call. So I think the rate is largely unchanged. Yes, weather can affected one way or the other but I don't know that I'd read too much into the fact that we didn't change or narrow the range.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that makes sense. And just lastly, Highway Bill question. You sounded like you were optimistic, so with the discussions in Congress were optimistic and I think this greater hope that we'll get it pass relatively soon. If so, could you maybe talk abo
componenttext: Okay, that makes sense. And just lastly, Highway Bill question. You sounded like you were optimistic, so with the discussions in Congress were optimistic and I think this greater hope that we'll get it pass relatively soon. If so, could you maybe talk about how this might end up impacting aggregates demand whether it's 2016, 2017 and what the medium to long-term impact would be from the highway bill?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- first of all, we're very optimistic that the bill's going to get past. We believe that the House will veto the bill this week them as a matter fact. When this happens it will give certainty of states. So we'll see a number of states which
componenttext: Yes, I think -- first of all, we're very optimistic that the bill's going to get past. We believe that the House will veto the bill this week them as a matter fact. When this happens it will give certainty of states. So we'll see a number of states which held back funds for large projects which is Arkansas has done that. We've seen -- Georgia's talking about it, a number of states have done it. They'll have certainty for the future going forward which will be very good for us. That is a compounding impact because a number of states have raised their funding. But you've got to remember, there's going to be a lag here between whether it's the increase in state funding or the federal funding, just because they've got to be able to get the funds and then they've got to be able to set up plants in the projects of the projects have start construction. So at best, I would say it would be end of '16 but I think the Highway bill impact of that, you really see towards the '16 and '17. What is hidden in there is you will start to see states have great relief with unlocking large multi your projects. But even if they said they were not doing it, they've got a number of them just that hesitant to do anything until they see that bill and that I think will flow through -- start to flow through in '16 but real impact I believe in '17. John?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Trey Grooms from Stephens.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015

componenttext: Just 1 point of clarity, you talked about kind some of the states there in the middle of the country that you guys are in that have been lag or split. Kind of going back to the slide deck, it looks like year-to-date, North Carolina was in the greater than 5% category but then if you look at just for the third quarter, it was in the flat to down category. Can you talk about kind of what's driving that if you seeing deceleration there? Just your thoughts around, that has kind of stood out to me.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't read anything into that, Trey. Last year, we had 2 very large painting jobs that we completed that weren't included in the shipments of this year. So I think that as you look at North Carolina, the demand is still healthy, that gets across
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't read anything into that, Trey. Last year, we had 2 very large painting jobs that we completed that weren't included in the shipments of this year. So I think that as you look at North Carolina, the demand is still healthy, that gets across a broad range of whether it's res, non-res, highway service structure. In fact, the DoT just passed the bill to substantially up their funding in that state. So overall, we feel good about our line, we feel good about demand growth. We think it will carry into '16 and we'll start to see some flow through of the $700 million increase in state highway spending. Now that won't come through right away but we'll start to see some other pride into 2016. But healthy.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Trey, you might even think that as an example in a know you know this very well. But it's a bit dangerous to extrapolate too much in our business from single quarter trends and that of course decide what we include both the quarterly view and the trailing
componenttext: Trey, you might even think that as an example in a know you know this very well. But it's a bit dangerous to extrapolate too much in our business from single quarter trends and that of course decide what we include both the quarterly view and the trailing 12 month per year-to-date view. Whether it's a volume trend or whether it's a pricing or cost trend, we're always going to encourage people that you also take a slightly longer term view and don't focus only on 1 quarter just because there's going to be so much volatility.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, understood. And also I guess, as a follow up, you guys had been fairly inquisitive, I guess, with some tuck in deals that seem to make a lot of sense. I guess, recently -- more recently, you've got of taken your foot off at least apparently taken you
componenttext: Yes, understood. And also I guess, as a follow up, you guys had been fairly inquisitive, I guess, with some tuck in deals that seem to make a lot of sense. I guess, recently -- more recently, you've got of taken your foot off at least apparently taken your foot off the gas a little bit there. Can you talk about, I guess, what you're seeing out there and how multiples are trending in the space and with that, backdrop, kind of update us on your thoughts about capital deployment.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll answer that John, are going to come when they come. We can control. Last year, they all seem to bunch up in the third quarter. I think what's important for us -- what's important is the discipline of what we buy, what we pay for and then how we integ
componenttext: I'll answer that John, are going to come when they come. We can control. Last year, they all seem to bunch up in the third quarter. I think what's important for us -- what's important is the discipline of what we buy, what we pay for and then how we integrate it. And we maybe real clear about the synergies that are unique to Vulcan and how we leverage those. So don't read because something happen that pipelines dried up because it hasn't and we are not -- we have not taken our foot off the accelerator at all.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And Trey, our overall capital allocation priorities adding the key messages our priorities have not changed and that we're making very good progress in the direction we've laid out. Just to quickly ticked through to a few, as I mentioned, our core CapEx,
componenttext: And Trey, our overall capital allocation priorities adding the key messages our priorities have not changed and that we're making very good progress in the direction we've laid out. Just to quickly ticked through to a few, as I mentioned, our core CapEx, reinvesting in the franchise, maintenance and capital, that remains on track and is being executed well. In terms of financial flexibility and overall balance sheet, making good progress and again, going forward, that's not use of cash to delever. Then we've also reduced our average issuance expense a bit. We will continue to look at that, of course. We remain committed to a dividend and the return of capital to shareholders through that dividend and that goes with earnings. That's a board decision, but nothing's changed there. Bob just touched on opportunities for M&A related growth where we have many, it's just a question of discipline and to some degree, some expectations that may be ahead of where they need to be. And then, of course, as we continue to generate substantial free cash flow through time comes operating cash flow, we expect to have a balanced approach of reinvesting that whether that's CapEx or M&by A growth and returning it whether that's through dividend or share repurchases.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, turning back to the highway bill. The proposal is out there have some level of inflation factored in there 6 year view. Can you just remind investors with the impact that greater than the actual dollar because of a bunch of projects and long-term nat
componenttext: Yes, turning back to the highway bill. The proposal is out there have some level of inflation factored in there 6 year view. Can you just remind investors with the impact that greater than the actual dollar because of a bunch of projects and long-term nature of projects, feel of -- we haven't had a six-year bill in so long sought of a refresher course of what to do with the numbers [indiscernible].

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me with the escalators and the said bill escalation is 3% annually which when you start a baseline of $41 billion, in year 3 it will be $45 billion, in year 6 it almost be $49 billion. That compares to a House bill, a draft house bill which is at
componenttext: Yes, let me with the escalators and the said bill escalation is 3% annually which when you start a baseline of $41 billion, in year 3 it will be $45 billion, in year 6 it almost be $49 billion. That compares to a House bill, a draft house bill which is at 1.9% annually, it's a little less. Now where we end up, our vote is for the Senate bill or something beyond that but we'll knows how that's going to turn out? While those increases are really important and we'll take all the funding we can get more importantly our country needs it. The confidence that this gives the states to move forward with long-term projects, a very large projects is really important. It also -- even if it's a six-year bill, it's only funded for 3, it locks in policy for 6 years which also builds confidence not just for the states but for the entire construction material cycle. So you'll see, this also builds that confidence we talk a lot about pricing momentum because there will be funding out there which means there will be projects out there which means there will be work out there for our customers and so, that will costs, confidence is really important not just for our customer base and pussy but also for the states that allow them to free up more work and drive demand.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: So it to present a 3% of implement, whatever, dollars allocated, can we see what it all the -- when they hit prior to the infrastructure this year as described in that?
componenttext: So it to present a 3% of implement, whatever, dollars allocated, can we see what it all the -- when they hit prior to the infrastructure this year as described in that?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And keep in mind that the parts of that funding that are not in federal are growing typically in our markets at a higher rate. So the state and local funding is growing at a substantially higher rate in many of our markets. There you see Federal doll
componenttext: Yes. And keep in mind that the parts of that funding that are not in federal are growing typically in our markets at a higher rate. So the state and local funding is growing at a substantially higher rate in many of our markets. There you see Federal dollars, but as Tom explained, long-term federal program is certainly, helpful to getting those state-level funds and revenue sources from being collected to actually, being spent on key projects. Along those lines, while we've had a number of states in our footprint increase their funding, we have a number of them right now that are critical that are debating increasing their funding. This will give confidence and it will give -- it creates momentum for those states to go do their part where they have much needed funding from a state and local perspective.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: And 1 point on the drive back, there was a talk of elimination of TIFIA. Is that still a topic that would be potentially on the table?
componenttext: And 1 point on the drive back, there was a talk of elimination of TIFIA. Is that still a topic that would be potentially on the table?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's really a reduction of TIFIA. TIFIA was budgeted at $1 billion a year. The drive back cost is down to $300 million. And actually, it's not that news for us because we weren't getting to -- $3 million it about as good as anybody got to, if they
componenttext: Yes, that's really a reduction of TIFIA. TIFIA was budgeted at $1 billion a year. The drive back cost is down to $300 million. And actually, it's not that news for us because we weren't getting to -- $3 million it about as good as anybody got to, if they got that for, to using those funds, so more than half of those funds went unused. That will go into work on intermodal and infrastructure projects. So what our view of that is, it's actually, pretty good news and when we get what we were using in TIFIA, the unused funding of that will go into the major projects to address intermodal and projects to actually ship materials on.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Wetenhall with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask you, you've had a lot of success in driving gross profit per ton from $2.55 up to $3.90. And like how should we think about your ability to keep driving that because I've got a credit, that's a ton of incremental improvement. So how muc
componenttext: Just wanted to ask you, you've had a lot of success in driving gross profit per ton from $2.55 up to $3.90. And like how should we think about your ability to keep driving that because I've got a credit, that's a ton of incremental improvement. So how much more runway is left?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's John. Our view is pretty straightforward. We think there's substantial runway left. As you recall from our Investor Day, and we laid this out, when the cash grows profit basis on Investor Day but as we continue to move forward in the recovery, c
componenttext: Bob, it's John. Our view is pretty straightforward. We think there's substantial runway left. As you recall from our Investor Day, and we laid this out, when the cash grows profit basis on Investor Day but as we continue to move forward in the recovery, continue to move back toward normal levels of demand, with the kind of pricing environment we expect, we should be able to continue confirming that incremental revenue at about 60% and doing that through this period of time gets us to a cash gross profit number that instead of being a little bit less than $6 this quarter, it will be a little bit above $8. So substantial room left. I' remind people that as an entire construction complex, more and more people are focused on earning fair returns on capital and earning these kind of incremental margins is consistent with that view. So we're very, very focused on it and we don't see anything from where we sit that should limit our progress on that dimension in the near term.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Cool. That's encouraging. Tom, I haven't heard you pull up in a long time. It's a really solid quarter operationally. It looks like you're getting price for service. In your forecast, you're looking at 7% price for the full year and you're obviously, gave
componenttext: Cool. That's encouraging. Tom, I haven't heard you pull up in a long time. It's a really solid quarter operationally. It looks like you're getting price for service. In your forecast, you're looking at 7% price for the full year and you're obviously, gave a confident view of demand trends going into '16. So I'm trying to reconcile of the bid how we should be thinking about pricing trends next year. You have a tough comp if you're up 7% this year. Should we expect pricing mix to be low single digits, and more like consistent with this year?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. It's all about the environment and I think in momentum, as you go into the fourth quarter of this year and into next year, censored earlier, we continue to see the demand going up, a very steady demand. It's about customer confidence. They have ba
componenttext: Thanks. It's all about the environment and I think in momentum, as you go into the fourth quarter of this year and into next year, censored earlier, we continue to see the demand going up, a very steady demand. It's about customer confidence. They have backlogs, they have backlogs with profitability in it, so they can raise their prices. So it's that confidence and the price of environment is so key, and as we talked about a lot, it's a very printable trends as that volume continues to trend up, pricing will follow it. So as we say earlier, it's the campaign of pricing in those compounding improvements over time. But going into the fourth quarter and into '16, what I can tell you is that pricing environment is very healthy.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you just get a little more specific in thinking about '16 to guide us? Is it more like, hey, we had great pricing, a lot of demand. We're up 7% in 2015. Against that comp would you expect to be at the low single-digit end of the range next year or i
componenttext: Could you just get a little more specific in thinking about '16 to guide us? Is it more like, hey, we had great pricing, a lot of demand. We're up 7% in 2015. Against that comp would you expect to be at the low single-digit end of the range next year or in the level more consistent with like 5% to 7% or 6% to 7% like this year in 2016?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's John, while I appreciate the effort, we're not going to give guidance for 2016 on this call. But I'll just reiterate what we've said which is, as we sit here today in early November, the core trends that we see in terms of demand recovery in the
componenttext: Bob, it's John, while I appreciate the effort, we're not going to give guidance for 2016 on this call. But I'll just reiterate what we've said which is, as we sit here today in early November, the core trends that we see in terms of demand recovery in the pricing environment, we see continuing into the fourth quarter and into 2016. So we don't see a significant shift in overall trajectory but we're not prepared at this time, to get specific guidance.

componenttextpreview: I think we've got some watch point. I'm not seeing deceleration anywhere but the watch points, as we said earlier, were 1 was non-res because of some leading indicators. As I said earlier, we're not seeing that on the ground. What we're bidding and what w
componenttext: I think we've got some watch point. I'm not seeing deceleration anywhere but the watch points, as we said earlier, were 1 was non-res because of some leading indicators. As I said earlier, we're not seeing that on the ground. What we're bidding and what we're shipping but we see that what we watch  and I think our folks are entitled to be very confident. The other place to watch is as we talked about earlier is to watch Texas, with the reduction in exploration drilling and the impact on jobs. While we've not seen any impact yet, it's been an argument in Texas where the rain in the first half of the year backlog of the year. So if there is a golf ball, it would be masked and that's the place we're watching but other than that, I feel we're pretty confident.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: This isn't a direct answer to your question but I would remind folks, as Tom was saying, both price and volume there is of course as there always has come a lot of variability across the portfolio geographically. So if you were to look at the rate of volu
componenttext: This isn't a direct answer to your question but I would remind folks, as Tom was saying, both price and volume there is of course as there always has come a lot of variability across the portfolio geographically. So if you were to look at the rate of volume growth or the rates of price growth, they were pretty well dispersed around the average and so we have -- of course as we get a little more clarity in our 2016 plans, we're going to have some geographies that are certainly, saw a growth in others and some faster growth than others and we'll have to incorporate all of that for our guidance next year.

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: Some question. You guys talked about bottlenecks in some places, this is something different from builders and contractors and guys who use contractors. Can you talk about how much of an impact that's having in  and if there's any rhyme or reason? Is it c
componenttext: Some question. You guys talked about bottlenecks in some places, this is something different from builders and contractors and guys who use contractors. Can you talk about how much of an impact that's having in  and if there's any rhyme or reason? Is it certain geographies, certain traits that you're seeing?

headline: Vulcan Materials Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Nov 03, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't know if I could but a pattern to it but we have seen a number of our customers running the bottlenecks which impacted third quarter shipments and will impact fourth quarter shipments. Now, that volume is not going away. It will be shipped. So whet
componenttext: I don't know if I could but a pattern to it but we have seen a number of our customers running the bottlenecks which impacted third quarter shipments and will impact fourth quarter shipments. Now, that volume is not going away. It will be shipped. So whether that's ready mix business, it's trucks and drivers, it's finishers in the asphalt business is crews, machines, and they're not going to ramp up. That will ramp up a little bit but they're not commit and just have a slowdown. I think what is key to what we in the third quarter seem to happen in the end of this year versus last year is the sense of urgency by our customers. When I say that, last year, if they got delayed, they just put it off for the next week or you tell the weather guy right. Whereas this year, we're seeing contractors work on Saturdays and Sundays. We're seeing a lot more sense of urgency of getting these jobs done which is very good news for us because that means they have backlogs now that they going to get this work done so they can get off to the other work which really signals from a macro perspective that this will work out there and we will continue to see the steady growth.
